name: Herbal Medicine
cautions: Potential interactions with medications
Allergies
Consideration of individual's specific health conditions
Professional guidance recommended for best practices
sourceReferences: Global Advances in Health and Medicine
historicalContext: Herbal medicine has been used worldwide since ancient times for both nutritional and medicinal purposes. It finds its roots in every culture including Asian (Ayurveda, Chinese), African, Middle Eastern, Greek, Roman, and Native American traditional medicine systems.
culturalSignificance: The use of plants as remedies is often integral to cultural identities and traditions, reflecting local flora and fauna as well as cultural preferences and beliefs about health and wellness. In many cultures, traditional healers remain the primary source of health care and medicine.
modernApplications: Modern herbal medicine uses extracts from plants to treat diseases and improve the general wellbeing of individuals. Today, it is practiced worldwide as a form of alternative medicine. Numerous studies have been done on the medicinal properties of plants, supporting their use in modern medicine

name: Echinacea
properties: Herbs in this category typically have immunomodulatory, antiviral, or antibacterial properties.
uses: These herbs are used to boost immunity, fight infections, provide allergy relief, support autoimmune health, and balance the immune system.
preparationMethods: Common preparations include herbal teas, tinctures, and capsules designed to enhance immune function.
cautions: Some immune-boosting herbs may not be suitable for individuals with autoimmune diseases due to their stimulating effects on the immune system.
growingInformation: Echinacea grows best in well-drained soil and full sun. It blooms in the mid to late summer and can tolerate drought conditions.
harvestingInformation: The leaves, roots, and flowers can be harvested when the plant is in full bloom for optimal potency.

dosageInformation.adult: 1 to 2 grams dried root or herb, as tea, three times daily, or 1 to 2 mL of tincture three times daily
dosageInformation.children: For children age 6 to 12, half the adult dosage
dosageInformation.elderly: Standard adult dosage, unless under medical supervision

shelfLife: Up to 2 years when stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Immunosuppressant medications
Caffeine
Liver enzymes inducing medications

name: Digestive Health
properties: Herbs for digestive health often possess anti-inflammatory
cautions: Certain herbs may interact with medications
exacerbate certain digestive conditions
It's important to use them appropriately
growingInformation: Varies by specific herb
harvestingInformation: Varies by specific herb
activeConstituents: Essential oils, flavonoids, phenolic acids, quinones, iridoids, tannins

dosageInformation.adult: Varies by specific herb and form
dosageInformation.children: Children under 2 years should not take herbal supplements unless directed by a doctor
dosageInformation.elderly: Elderly individuals should consult a healthcare provider before starting any new herbal regimen, dosages often vary based on overall health status

shelfLife: 1-3 years, depending on specific herb and storage conditions
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants, sedatives, immunosuppressive drugs, and others depending on specific herb

name: Mental and Emotional Health
cautions: Interactions with psychiatric medications
Potential for exacerbating certain mental health conditions
historicalContext: Mental and emotional health promotion has been important throughout human history, with various methods developed across different cultures to preserve mental well-being.
culturalSignificance: Practices for promoting mental and emotional health are integral in many cultures, often ingrained in traditional medicine, religious practices, and societal norms.
modernApplications: Contemporary applications range from psychotherapy techniques to the use of medication, dietary supplements, mindfulness practices, and lifestyle adjustments.
relatedRemedies: St. John's Wort for mood disorders
Lavender oil for stress and anxiety
Omega-3 fatty acids for cognitive functioning

name: Herbalism
preparationMethods: Varies widely depending on cultural and geographical context, includes teas, tinctures, poultices, and more
cautions: Herbal medicine should be practiced with knowledge of the herb's effects and potential interactions with other treatments. It's important to consider individual health conditions and consult with a healthcare professional.
historicalContext: Herbalism traces its roots back to ancient civilizations. It is known to be the foundation of modern pharmacology and has been practised and documented by various cultures throughout history, including the Chinese, Indians, Egyptians, and Greeks.
culturalSignificance: Herbalism plays a significant role in various cultures as it's considered a traditional method of healing. It signifies the harmony between humans and nature and postulates that every plant has a medicinal use. In many societies, herbalists are held in high regard due to their knowledge of medicinal plants and their healing properties.
modernApplications: Today, herbalism has gained renewed interest due to a global shift towards natural and holistic healthcare. It is utilized in preventing and treating a variety of conditions, improving overall well-being, and is applied in various forms like dietary supplements, teas, skin creams, and more.
sourceReferences: World Health Organization. Traditional Medicine Strategy 2014-2023. WHO, 2013.
National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health. 'Herbs At a Glance.' U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, 2020.

name: Herbalism in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)
properties: Uses herbs to harmonize body's yin and yang
uses: Part of a comprehensive system including acupuncture, dietary therapy, and qi cultivation
Used to treat various health conditions, including digestive issues, respiratory issues, and chronic pain
preparationMethods: Specific to TCM practices, often involves decoctions and complex formulations
cautions: Requires deep understanding of TCM principles and diagnosis by a qualified practitioner
Herbs used in TCM can interact with other medications, leading to adverse reactions
historicalContext: Herbalism in Traditional Chinese Medicine originated over 2000 years ago and is one of the world's oldest forms of healthcare.
culturalSignificance: Herbalism plays a pivotal role in TCM and is deeply embedded in the Chinese culture. Herbal remedies are often used in conjunction with other TCM practices like acupuncture, massage, dietary therapy, and qi cultivation to promote natural healing.
modernApplications: Today, TCM herbalism is not only adopted in China but also globally for its integrative approach to healthcare. Many modern practitioners integrate TCM principles and herbal solutions into their practices.

name: Herbalism in Ayurveda
properties: Categorizes herbs based on effects on body's doshas (Vata, Pitta, Kapha)
preparationMethods: Includes a wide range of preparations from simple teas to complex herbal compounds
cautions: Selection of herbs should be based on an individual's dosha balance, ideally determined by an experienced Ayurvedic practitioner
sourceReferences: Lad, V. (2002). Textbook of Ayurveda. Albuquerque: Ayurvedic Press.
Sharma, H. (2013). Ayurvedic Healing: A Comprehensive Guide. Delhi: Motilal Banarsidass.
historicalContext: Ayurveda is a traditional system of medicine that originated in India over 5000 years ago. Herbalism plays a key role in this holistic approach to health and well-being.
culturalSignificance: Ayurveda is integral to Indian culture and spiritual practices, and its herbal remedies are passed down through generations. It enjoys a significant global attention for its natural, holistic approach towards health and wellness.
modernApplications: Ayurveda and its herbal remedies are currently used worldwide in alternative and complementary medicine. Herbalism in Ayurveda also influenced other medical systems such as traditional Chinese medicine and Tibetan medicine.

name: Herbalism in Greco-Roman Tradition
properties: Substantial influence on modern pharmacology and botany
uses: Wide range of medicinal applications documented by ancient physicians
Basis for studies in phytotherapy and naturopathic medicine
preparationMethods: and other forms based on documented knowledge
cautions: While historical, knowledge from this tradition forms the basis of much of modern herbal practice; still, contemporary knowledge and safety practices should be applied
Some plants or methods may be outdated or disproven by modern science
historicalContext: Herbalism in the Greco-Roman tradition has roots in the ancient Empires of Greece and Rome, spanning from the time of Hippocrates (circa 5th century BCE) through the Roman Empire, and even into the Middle Ages and Renaissance via Arabic influences.
culturalSignificance: Greco-Roman herbalism played a significant role in health care in ancient times and was often linked to the mythical and divine. Its influence continues to resonate in modern Western medicine, both in the study of herbal remedies and the broader field of pharmacology.
modernApplications: Modern herbalists and practitioners of holistic medicine often draw upon the knowledge and principles of the Greco-Roman herbal tradition, while also integrating updated science and contemporary safety practices. This historical knowledge is also useful in archaeological and cultural studies.

name: Herbalism in Indigenous Peoples of the Americas
properties: Developed complex herbal systems, often blending with European methods
Methods often revolve around the belief in the spiritual power of plants
Customs include sacred rituals, drumming, and chanting
uses: Varied, based on local plant life and cultural traditions
Used for medicinal purposes, such as treating various illnesses and conditions
Used in rituals, ceremonies, and in certain cultural practices
preparationMethods: Included unique preparations specific to each culture's traditions
Herbs might be prepared as teas, poultices, or incorporated into food and drink
Often applied in combination with other elements such as minerals, animal parts, and spiritual rituals
cautions: Knowledge of these practices often passed down through generations, requiring respect for cultural traditions and understanding of specific herbal uses
Certain techniques, rituals, or uses may be sacred or privileged information within a specific culture
evidenceLevel: Low (Due to lack of scientific studies, historical and cultural context is the primary source of information)
sourceReferences: Native American Medicinal Plants- An Ethnobotanical Dictionary(2009)
American Indian Healing Arts: Herbs, Rituals, and Remedies for Every Season of Life (1999)
historicalContext: Indigenous peoples of the Americas have a wealth of traditional knowledge about their local environment, including the medical uses of plants. This knowledge has been documented by ethnobotanists and is now being further researched for its potential applications in modern medicine.
culturalSignificance: Herbalism is deeply woven into the cultural fabric of many Indigenous Peoples of the Americas. It is often tied to spiritual practices and beliefs, helping shape identities, customs, and worldviews.
modernApplications: Modern herbalists and researchers are increasingly interested in indigenous herbal practices for potential medicinal applications. Aspects of herbalism are adopted in holistic and alternative medicine.

name: Chamomile
uses: Helps with skin conditions like eczema
preparationMethods: Can also be used in baths
cautions: Rare allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to the Asteraceae family
May cause drowsiness. Do not operate heavy machinery after consumption
Not recommended for pregnant women
interactions: May interact with anticoagulant/antiplatelet drugs, CNS depressants, and alcohol
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH)
growingInformation: Chamomile is a hardy annual plant that prefers well-drained soil and full sun exposure. It can be easily grown from seed and typically blooms from late spring through early autumn.
harvestingInformation: The flowers can be harvested in the summer when fully bloomed. They should be dried in a cool, dark place before storage.

dosageInformation.adult: 3-4 cups of tea daily, or as directed by a healthcare professional
dosageInformation.children: 1-2 cups of tea daily, or as directed by a healthcare professional
dosageInformation.elderly: 2-3 cups of tea daily, or as directed by a healthcare professional

shelfLife: Dried flowers can last for up to a year if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Keep in an airtight container

name: Echinacea
uses: Helps alleviate cold and flu symptoms
preparationMethods: Simmer in hot water with elderberries and ginger, then steep and add honey
Can also be taken as a tincture or capsule
cautions: May interact with certain medications and conditions. Consult a healthcare provider if unsure
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Echinacea for preventing and treating the common cold. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2014.
Echinacea. National Centers for Complementary and Integrative Health. 2021.
growingInformation: Full sun; well-drained soil; US zones 3-8
harvestingInformation: Harvest in late summer or fall
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with immuno-modulating drugs

name: Ginger
cautions: High doses can interact with blood thinners and cause heartburn
People with gallstones should consult a doctor before consuming
May lower blood sugar - precaution for diabetics
growingInformation: Tropical climate, fertile and well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest after leaves have died down, usually 8-10 months after planting

dosageInformation.elderly: start with lower dose, consult a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Fresh root - 2-3 weeks refrigerated, Dried powder - 2-3 years in airtight container
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Blood thinners, Diabetes medications, High blood pressure drugs

name: Turmeric
cautions: May interact with blood thinners and other medications
growingInformation: Tropical perennial plant that prefers temperatures between 68-86°F (20-30°C). Requires substantial amount of rainfall throughout the year.
harvestingInformation: Typically harvested 8 to 10 months after planting, when leaves and stems are dry.

dosageInformation.adults: Standard dose: 500-2,000 mg of Turmeric per day, containing around 60-100mg of Curcumin.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Keep in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners
May cause stomach upset in conjunction with other medications
May interfere with drugs that reduce stomach acid
Can interfere with diabetes medications

name: Garlic
uses: Part of an arterial cleanse mix for cardiovascular health.
Used to reduce cholesterol and blood pressure.
preparationMethods: Crushed and mixed with warm water, ginger, and lemon juice.
cautions: Not recommended for people on blood thinning medication.
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained soil, full sun and cool temperatures. Plant in the fall for a summer harvest.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the lower leaves begin to yellow and fall off, typically in summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 600-900mg (in divided doses) daily standardized garlic powder

shelfLife: Fresh bulb vase life is 3-5 months, dried powder can last upto 4 years if stored correctly
storageInstructions: Store fresh bulbs in a cool, dark, dry place. Store dried powder in air-tight containers in a cool, dry place.

medications: Blood-thinners such as Warfarin, NSAIDS, HIV medication can have interactions with garlic

name: Milk Thistle
preparationMethods: Infusion from dried flowers and leaves
Extract from seeds can be used in tinctures
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Can interact with liver medications
growingInformation: Grows best in sunny location in well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest seeds in late summer, flowers and leaves in mid-summer
cautions: None specified
Not recommended for children
May interact with certain medications

name: Dandelion Root
uses: traditionally used in herbal medicine to stimulate appetite
Sources: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growing_information: Dandelions are hardy biennials that can grow in nearly any temperature or soil condition. They prefer full sun, but can tolerate partial shade. They grow best in rich, well-drained soil.
harvesting_information: Harvest roots in early spring or late fall when plants are dormant and have stored nutrients in the roots. Harvest leaves anytime during the growing season.
active_constituents: Taraxacin, taraxacoside, inulin, phenolic acids, flavonoids, minerals and vitamins
shelf_life: Store dried root up to a year
storage_instructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight

interactions_with_medications.Diuretics: Dandelion has diuretic properties and may increase the effects of diuretic drugs
interactions_with_medications.Blood-thinners: Dandelion may affect blood clotting and increase the risk of bleeding when taken with drugs that increase the risk of bleeding

cautions: May interact with diuretics or drugs that affect blood clotting
Consult with a healthcare provider if you have gallbladder disease

name: Nettle
uses: Potentially relieves benign prostatic hyperplasia symptoms
preparationMethods: Can be consumed as a tea
Or added to foods like soups and stews
cautions: People with certain health conditions should consult a healthcare provider before use
May interact with blood-thinning medications
May lower blood sugar levels
sourceReferences: Healthline: 6 Benefits of Stinging Nettle (Plus Side Effects)
growingInformation: Tolerates a variety of soils, prefers partial shade, propagates easily from seeds or cuttings
harvestingInformation: Harvest young leaves in spring, roots in autumn; always wear gloves to avoid stings
activeConstituents: Vitamins: A, C, K, and several B
Minerals: Calcium, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Blood thinners
Diabetes medications

name: Parsley
uses: As a flavoring and detoxifying agent in foods
preparationMethods: Blend 1 handful of Parsley with cucumber, green apple, and lemon juice for a kidney-cleansing juice.
cautions: Ensure proper hydration when consuming diuretic herbs.
growingInformation: Parsley is a biennial plant that requires rich, well-drained soil and full to partial sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Harvest parsley in the morning when the plant's oils are at their peak. Cut the stems close to ground level.

dosageInformation.adult: Up to one bunch a day when used in food.
dosageInformation.children: Use smaller quantities, about half the adult dose.

shelfLife: Fresh parsley should be used within a week, while dried parsley has a shelf life of about a year.
storageInstructions: Store fresh parsley in the refrigerator wrapped in a slightly damp paper towel. Dried parsley should be stored in a cool, dark place in an airtight container.

interactionsWithMedications.Diuretic medications: May increase the effects of these drugs.
interactionsWithMedications.Anticoagulant medications: Parsley may enhance the blood-thinning effects of these drugs.

name: Cleavers
uses: Treatment of skin conditions like psoriasis and eczema
preparationMethods: Applied topically as infused oil or tincture
cautions: Avoid during pregnancy or breastfeeding
May cause allergic reaction in people sensitive to the Rubiaceae plant family
growingInformation: Cleavers prefer partial shade and moist soil. They are often found in gardens, fields, and along roadsides.
harvestingInformation: Cleavers should be harvested before they flower, typically in early to mid-spring.

dosageInformation.adult: Infusion: Pour 1 cup of boiling water onto 2-4 teaspoons of dried herb and let infuse for 10-15 minutes. Drink three times a day.
dosageInformation.elderly: Infusion: Pour 1 cup of boiling water onto 1-2 teaspoons of dried herb and let infuse for 10-15 minutes. Drink twice a day.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place in an airtight container.

medications: May decrease the effectiveness of certain medications like lithium

name: Burdock Root
preparationMethods: Simmer in water for 15 minutes alongside Dandelion Root
cautions: People with allergies to items in the Asteraceae/Compositae family should use with caution. Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women.
growingInformation: Burdock is a hardy biennial plant that thrives in full sun or light shade, and prefers deep, well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Roots should be harvested in late summer or early autumn of the plant's first year.
activeConstituents: Inulin, mucilage, and various antioxidant polyphenols

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 grams of burdock daily as part of a tea or other preparation
dosageInformation.elderly: Adhere to adult dosage; monitor for gastrointestinal discomfort

shelfLife: Stored properly, burdock root should last for about a year.
storageInstructions: Dried burdock root should be stored in a cool, dry, and dark place in an airtight container.
interactions: May increase the risk of bleeding if taken with anticoagulant drugs. Can impact blood sugar levels; people with diabetes should consult a healthcare provider before use.

name: Uva Ursi
cautions: Not for long-term use
Avoid if pregnant or nursing
May interact with diuretic and anti-inflammatory medicines
sourceReferences: Kowalczyk, M., & Jankowska, K. (2016). Chemical composition of the bearberry leaf extract (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi L. Spreng.)—a study of the antioxidant effects dependent on extraction conditions. Herba Polonica, 62(3).
Head, K. A. (2008). Natural approaches to prevention and treatment of infections of the lower urinary tract. Alternative medicine review, 13(3), 227-244.
growingInformation: Uva Ursi thrives in lightly shaded areas with well-drained soil and a pH of 6.8 to 7.2.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves in the second or third year of growth during summer or autumn.
activeConstituents: Arbutin, tannins, flavonoids, and volatile oils

dosageInformation.adults: 500-1000 mg dried leaf or 2-4 mL liquid extract three times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: 500-1000 mg dried leaf or 2-4 mL liquid extract three times daily, with physician consultation

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight. Keep out of the reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diuretic and anti-inflammatory medicines

name: Fennel
uses: Used in a vision-boosting tea to enhance visual clarity and reduce eye strain.
Used to improve digestion and treat flatulence.
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water with Rosemary for 10-15 minutes.
Could be powdered for use in a decoction.
cautions: May interact with certain medications and is not recommended for pregnant women without consulting a healthcare provider. People with estrogen-dependent cancers should avoid it.
growingInformation: Best grown in full sun with well-drained soil. It could reach a height of 5 feet.
harvestingInformation: Seeds are usually harvested in late summer, while the leaves can be picked as needed.

dosageInformation.adults: Usually 1-2 tsp of dried seeds in hot water as tea.

shelfLife: Can last 1-2 years, depending on storage conditions.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place and away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Oestrogen pills
Ciprofloxacin

name: Peppermint
preparationMethods: Applied topically in oil form for headaches
cautions: May cause heartburn in some individuals
Avoid use with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Avoid use if allergic to peppermint
growingInformation: Prefer well-drained soil and partial shade. Water regularly.
harvestingInformation: Harvest just as flower buds appear, typically in mid-summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 drops of essential oil / 1-2 teaspoon of dried leaves

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with medications for diabetes, high blood pressure, and acid reflux

name: Calendula
uses: Combined with Comfrey in a balm for external application on sore areas
Infused in tea to soothe digestive issues
preparationMethods: Infuse in olive oil over low heat before mixing with beeswax
Steep in boiling water for 15 minutes for tea
cautions: Rarely, may cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to the Asteraceae family
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult a healthcare professional before use
growingInformation: Grows best in full sun or light shade in well-drained soil. Easy to grow from seeds.
harvestingInformation: Pick flowers in full bloom in early morning after the dew has dried.

dosageInformation.adult: Topical ointments can be applied to affected area 2-3 times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: Topical ointments can be applied to affected area 2-3 times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a dark, cool, and dry place. Keep out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with sedative medications due to possible sedative effects

name: Neem
uses: Used in hair nourishing oils for scalp health
Component in various skincare and dental hygiene products
preparationMethods: Simmer neem powder in sesame oil, strain and store
Infuse neem leaves in hot water for a herbal tea
cautions: May cause an allergic reaction in some people
Not recommended during pregnancy and nursing
sourceReferences: Kumar VS, Navaratnam V. Neem (Azadirachta indica): Prehistory to contemporary medicinal uses to humankind. Asian Pac J Trop Biomed. 2013;3(7):505–514. doi:10.1016/S2221-1691(13)60105-7
growingInformation: Neem trees prefer hot climates, and they can handle poor, rocky soils and drought conditions. The tree can be propagated through seed, semi-hardwood cuttings, and root suckers.
harvestingInformation: Neem leaves and seeds can be harvested year-round, but the flowers bloom in the spring.

dosageInformation.adult: 5-6 leaves per day for general health maintenance. For specific conditions, consult a healthcare professional.
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under the age of 12 without professional advice.
dosageInformation.elderly: Same as adult dosage, but attention should be given to interactions with other medications.

shelfLife: Neem oil and leaves are best used fresh but can be stored in a cool, dark place for up to 2 years.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diabetes medications and medications processed by the liver.

name: Oregon Grape Root
growingInformation: Oregon Grape Root thrives in well-drained soil with full sun or partial shade. It is a hardy plant and can tolerate cold, drought and poor soil conditions.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in the fall or early spring, when the plant's alkaloids are most concentrated.

dosageInformation.children: Use is not recommended for children under 12
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with a lower dose, under medical supervision

storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight. Ensure the container is tightly sealed to preserve the potency of the herb.
interactionsWithMedications: May interfere with the absorption of tetracycline and other similar antibiotics. Can potentially interact with anticoagulants, blood thinners, and blood pressure medications. Always consult with a healthcare professional before use.
cautions: Contains berberine, which may interact with certain medications
Not recommended for pregnant or nursing women
Should not be used for more than three weeks without a break

name: Licorice Root
uses: Incorporated in teas to support bone health and balance hormones
Commonly used as a flavoring ingredient in candies and beverages
preparationMethods: Steep 1 teaspoon dried Licorice Root with other herbs in hot water for 15 minutes
cautions: High doses can lead to hypertension and lower potassium levels
Should not be used by pregnant women and people with heart problems
growingInformation: Licorice roots are typically grown in deep, sandy soils. The plant prefer areas with full sun exposure.
harvestingInformation: Licorice roots are often harvested in the late fall and winter, usually 2-3 years after planting.

dosageInformation.elderly: Dose should be reduced for the elderly due to increased susceptibility to side effects.

shelfLife: When stored properly, licorice root can last up to 3 years.
storageInstructions: Licorice root should be stored in a cool, dark place in an airtight container to maintain its potency.
interactionsMedications: Can interact with Warfarin, Diuretics, and Corticosteroids.

name: Celery
cautions: Allergy for some individuals
Can increase sensitivity to sunlight
growingInformation: Cool season plant, grown in drained soil with enough moisture
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the stalks are 8 to 10 inches tall, in the morning for maximum crispness
storageInstructions: Wrap in plastic and store in the fridge
interactionsWithMedications: Can enhance effect of blood-thinning drugs
Increases effects of photosensitizing drugs

name: Flaxseed
properties: Provides a sustainable source of omegas and a balanced mix of soluble and insoluble fiber.
preparationMethods: Mix ground flaxseed into warm water until fully dissolved.
Can also be added to foods like oatmeal or smoothies.
cautions: Consume with plenty of water to ensure proper digestion.
Shouldn't be consumed raw or unripe due to harmful compounds.
sourceReferences: Nutrition Facts for Flaxseeds. (n.d.). Self Nutrition Data. Retrieved from https://nutritiondata.self.com/facts/nut-and-seed-products/3163/2
Flaxseed. (2019). National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH). Retrieved from https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/flaxseed
growingInformation: Flaxseed is a cool-weather crop and grows best in northern climates with a long spring season.
harvestingInformation: Flaxseeds are ready to harvest 30-45 days after the plant flowers when the bolls turn brown.
shelfLife: Ground flaxseed: 6-16 weeks in cool, dark, dry storage. Whole flaxseed: up to 1 year.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place. Preferably in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMedications: Can potentially interfere with diabetes medication, blood thinners, and medication relating to hormone-sensitive conditions.

name: Chia Seeds
preparationMethods: Soak in liquid to form a gel
cautions: Shouldn't be consumed raw
growingInformation: Thrives in dry, warm climates. Can withstand drought.
harvestingInformation: Harvested when plant is dry, typically after bloom season.
activeConstituents: Fiber, Omega-3 fatty acids, proteins, antioxidants

dosageInformation.adult: 15-20 grams per day, not to exceed 40 grams

storageInstructions: Store in a dry, cool place, away from sunlight, preferably in an airtight container

name: Apple
growingInformation: Apple trees prefer temperate climate, and they need at least 6 hours of sunlight daily. They will bloom in the spring, with the fruits ready to harvest in the fall.
harvestingInformation: Apples are ripe and ready to pick when they come off the branch with a twist, and their color is fully developed.
activeConstituents: Dietary fiber, vitamin C, potassium, and antioxidants

dosageInformation.children: Depends on child's age and size, generally half an apple

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. For longer storage, refrigeration is recommended.
interactionsWithMedications: Apples can decrease the absorption of certain medications. Consult a healthcare provider for individual advice.

name: Banana
cautions: People with kidney disease should limit consumption due to high potassium content

harvestingInformation.harvestTime: When the fruit stalks turn yellow

storageInstructions: Store at room temperature away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Potassium-sparing diuretics

name: Epsom Salt
uses: Can be used as a laxative for occasional constipation
preparationMethods: Mix with other ingredients and add to bathwater
Dissolve a small quantity in water for oral consumption as laxative
cautions: Do not use as a laxative without consulting with a healthcare provider
Avoid overuse as can cause dryness or irritation of the skin
purityRequirements: Should be 100% pure Epsom salt, no added fragrances or additives
sourcingInformation: Commonly available in drugstores and online

dosageInformation.Bath soak: 2 cups per standard-sized bathtub, soak for at least 15 minutes

shelfLife: Epsom salt does not expire but should be kept dry
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place

name: Baking Soda
preparationMethods: Mix with other ingredients and add to bathwater
cautions: Avoid high doses due to potential harm to kidneys and heart
Not recommended for people on a sodium-restricted diet
sourcingInformation: Available in grocery and health food stores
dosageInformation: Talk to your healthcare provider for dosage recommendation
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Keep container tightly closed to prevent absorption of moisture and odors
evidenceLevel: Moderate evidence supporting usage for indigestion and stomach acid

name: Rosemary
cautions: Excessive consumption can lead to gastrointestinal discomfort
sourceReferences: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition
growingInformation: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil. It can survive in a variety of climates.
harvestingInformation: Harvest just before the plant blooms for best flavor and potency.

dosageInformation.adults: 1-2 grams of dried leaves per day

shelfLife: Dried rosemary can last up to a year if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: May affect medications for high blood pressure or diabetes

name: Kale
cautions: Over-consumption can lead to bloating, gas and other types of stomach discomfort
SourceReferences: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
growingInformation: Kale prefers cool conditions and can handle frost, plant in early spring and harvest in mid-fall.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves when they are as big as your hand, always leaving the center leaves for continued growth.
storageInstructions: Store unwashed kale in a plastic bag in the refrigerator.
interactionsWithMedications: Kale can interfere with the absorption of calcium

name: Coconut Water
cautions: Not specified in the text
Overconsumption may cause electrolyte imbalance

name: Herbal Medicine Storage and Maintenance
uses: The text outlines the importance of proper storage and maintenance practices for herbs and herbal preparations to preserve their potency and extend their shelf life. Key factors that degrade the quality of herbs include light, heat, and moisture.

Often used as part of holistic and alternative medicine, properly stored and maintained herbs and herbal preparations can maintain their curative powers for longer periods, improving their effectiveness.
preparationMethods: Dried herbs should be stored in dark glass jars or opaque containers to block out light, in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight and humidity, within a temperature range of 60-70°F (15-21°C). Tinctures should be kept in dark glass bottles in a cool, dark place, while infused oils and salves require refrigeration or cool, dry conditions to prevent rancidity and spoilage.
cautions: Regular checks for signs of spoilage are recommended, including discoloration, loss of fragrance, or mold in dried herbs; change in smell or cloudiness in tinctures; and off smell or separation in oils and salves. Spoiled products should be discarded.
sourceReferences: The Green Pharmacy: The Ultimate Compendium of Natural Remedies from the World's Foremost Authority on Healing Herbs, James A. Duke, 1997.
historicalContext: The practice of herbal medicine storage and maintenance has been a part of traditional medicine practices across cultures globally. Proper storage techniques have been part of oral and written medicinal traditions to ensure the potency of herbal treatments.
culturalSignificance: In many cultures, traditional medicine practices remain significant, including the careful storage and maintenance of herbs as part of medicinal practices. Proper storage can be seen as a sign of respect for the curative properties of nature.
modernApplications: With the recent resurgence in popularity of natural and holistic health approaches, the practice of proper herbal medicine storage and maintenance has garnered increasing attention. Current practices employ a mix of traditional knowledge and modern scientific understanding.

name: Understanding Body Systems
uses: Provides an overview of the major body systems (digestive, respiratory, circulatory, immune, nervous, endocrine, musculoskeletal, and urinary) and their roles in maintaining health and function. Emphasizes the interconnectedness of these systems and the importance of holistic health approaches to address imbalances.
Informing fitness and nutrition programs to optimize health and performance by understanding the role and function of various body systems.
cautions: The text suggests that disruptions in one body system can have a ripple effect on others, highlighting the need for a comprehensive understanding of body systems to effectively use herbs and natural remedies for restoring harmony.
historicalContext: The understanding of body systems dates back to ancient times, with civilizations like the Greeks and Egyptians having some grasp of human anatomy and physiology. Advancements in science and medicine over centuries have led to sophisticated knowledge of individual body systems and their interconnectedness.
culturalSignificance: In many cultures, understanding body systems forms the foundation of traditional healing methods such as Ayurveda and Traditional Chinese Medicine, both of which emphasize a holistic approach to health and wellness.
modernApplications: Facilitating the development of treatment approaches for various diseases by understanding their effects on different body systems.
Supporting the development and provision of health education to promote self-management of health and wellness.
sourceReferences: Marieb, Elaine N.; Hoehn, Katja (2013). Human Anatomy & Physiology (9th ed.). Pearson Education. ISBN 978-0-321-74326-8.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology (13th ed.). Elsevier.

name: Slippery Elm
uses: Effective for soothing allergy-related throat irritation and discomfort
Helps relieve gastrointestinal symptoms like heartburn and inflammatory bowel disease
preparationMethods: Powder form mixed with Licorice Root powder and honey to create lozenges
cautions: May interfere with the absorption of certain medications
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult with a health professional before use
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained soil and full to partial sun.
harvestingInformation: Bark should be harvested in early spring.

dosageInformation.adults: 1-3 grams of powder up to 3 times daily
dosageInformation.children: Consult a healthcare professional for appropriate dosage
dosageInformation.elderly: Lower dosage may be needed, consult a healthcare professional

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: May interfere with absorption of orally administered drugs

name: Mullein
uses: Natural remedy for asthma and bronchitis
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water for 20 minutes, can add honey
Used as a tincture or essential oil
cautions: None specified
Avoid using with other pharmaceutical expectorants
Not recommended for pregnant women
growingInformation: Commonly found in fields, waste places, and along roadsides. Prefers sandy or limestone soil with good sun exposure.
harvestingInformation: Leaves are harvested in the summer and flowers are collected shortly after opening.

dosageInformation.adults: As a tea, infuse 1-2 teaspoons of dried leaves in hot water, up to three times daily.
dosageInformation.children: Consult a healthcare professional before use.
dosageInformation.elderly: As a tea, infuse 1-2 teaspoons of dried leaves in hot water, up to two times daily.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMedications: May enhance the effect of other pharmaceutical expectorants. Seek medical advice before use.

name: Hawthorn
uses: Strengthens heart function and enhances circulation.
Helps reduce symptoms of heart failure.
preparationMethods: Can be steeped in water to make tea.
cautions: May interact with heart medications.
Consult your healthcare provider before use if pregnant or breastfeeding.
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Hawthorn thrives in sunny, well-drained areas. It is a hardy plant and can withstand cold climates.
harvestingInformation: Leaves and flowers should be harvested in spring before the berries emerge. Berries are harvested in fall when they are fully ripe.
shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Make sure the container is tightly sealed.
interactionsWithMedications: Beta blockers
Calcium channel blockers
Digoxin
Phenylephrine

name: Skullcap
uses: Reduces stress and prevents emotional eating
helps soothe nerves in order to induce relaxation
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water for tea
cautions: None specified
Pregnant and lactating women should avoid use
May interfere with sedatives or other medication affecting the nervous system
growingInformation: Requires partially shaded area with well drained soil, hardy in temperate climates
harvestingInformation: Best harvested in summer when plants are flowering

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 grams of dried herb brewed into tea, 3x daily

shelfLife: Dried skullcap herb can be stored for up to one year
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with sedatives or other medications affecting the nervous system
May interact with liver medicines

name: Valerian
uses: Reduce the time it takes to fall asleep
May also be used to alleviate anxiety and help control stress
Helps relax the central nervous system and relax muscles
cautions: May interact with sedatives and cause drowsiness
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery after taking valerian
Not recommended for children, pregnant women or nursing mothers
growingInformation: Valerian is a perennial plant that prefers full sun or partial shade and well-drained soil. It blooms in the summer and can grow up to 5 feet tall.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in the fall of the second year of growth.

dosageInformation.elderly: Begin with lower dosage, considering slower metabolism

shelfLife: Up to three years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight. Keep out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with sedatives, anesthetics, and certain antidepressants. Always consult with a healthcare provider before use.
sourceReferences: National Institutes of Health, National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health

name: Holy Basil
preparationMethods: Commonly consumed as a tea or tincture, can also be used in traditional Indian cooking
cautions: May lower blood sugar levels; those with diabetes should monitor their blood sugar closely
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult a healthcare professional before use
sourceReferences: Cohen MM. Tulsi - Ocimum sanctum: A herb for all reasons. J Ayurveda Integr Med. 2014
Sampath, S., et.al. (2015) Holy basil (Ocimum sanctum Linn.) leaf extract enhances specific cognitive parameters in healthy adult volunteers: A placebo controlled study. Indian J Physiol Pharmacol.
growingInformation: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil, grows best in warm climates
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves throughout the growing season for fresh use
dosage: Adults: 500 mg of dried leaves traditionally used 3 times daily. Children and Elderly: consult a medical professional
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactions: May interact with anticoagulants, antiplatelet drugs, and hypoglycemic medications. Consult a healthcare professional before use

name: Boswellia
uses: Can help relieve symptoms of asthma
preparationMethods: Simmered in olive oil for a pain relief oil
Combined with alcohol for a tincture
Taken in capsule or tablet form for internal use
cautions: May interact with anti-inflammatory and cholesterol-lowering medications
Not advised during pregnancy or breastfeeding
growingInformation: Boswellia is a tree that prefers a dry, desert-like environment and is native to the Arabian Peninsula and northeastern Africa.
harvestingInformation: The tree's bark is cut, allowing the resin to exude and harden into a natural oleoresin which is harvested.

dosageInformation.children: Consult a healthcare professional before use
dosageInformation.elderly: As adult, unless there are specific health considerations.

storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place and away from direct sunlight. Keep out of reach of children

medications: May interact with anti-inflammatory drugs by increasing their effects

name: Comfrey
uses: Used in a balm for bone and joint pain
Applied topically to reduce swelling and bruising
preparationMethods: Infuse in olive oil with Calendula and beeswax to create a healing balm
cautions: Not recommended for internal use or on open wounds due to liver toxicity risks
sourceReferences: Rodrigues, Marcos, and Naoufel M. Zamzami. "Comfrey: A Clinical Overview." Phytotherapy Research 26.10 (2012): 1441-1448.
growingInformation: Thrives well in well-drained, moist soil and full to partial sunlight. Grows optimally in USDA zones 4 to 9.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves in late spring to early summer. Harvest roots in the spring or late fall.

dosageInformation.adults: Apply balm 3 times daily on affected area
dosageInformation.elderly: Apply balm twice daily on affected area

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Oral anticoagulants
Antiplatelet drugs

name: Dandelion
preparationMethods: Simmer roots in water, strain, cool, and add honey
Can also be consumed as a tea or in salad
cautions: May interact with diuretics or lithium
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult healthcare practitioner before use
growingInformation: Full sun or partial shade, moist well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest in early spring or late fall, include the root

dosageInformation.Elderly: Start with lower dosage; adjust as needed

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Diuretics
Lithium

name: Basil
preparationMethods: Mix powder with Thyme powder and fill capsules
Can be used fresh in cooking or dried for tea
cautions: Avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding due to potential blood thinning effect
May cause low blood sugar levels in diabetics

harvestingInformation.whenToHarvest: Early morning, just after dew has dried
harvestingInformation.howToHarvest: Pinch off individual leaves or entire stem just above two leaves

storageInstructions: Store in cool, dry, dark place in airtight container

interactionsWithMedications.diabetesMedication: Monitor blood sugar level regularly. Dose adjustment may be required

name: Oregano
uses: Used in cooking for its health benefits
preparationMethods: Used fresh or dried in culinary dishes
cautions: Essential oil should be diluted before use on skin or in internal applications
Can cause upset stomach and other digestive discomfort if taken in large amounts
sourceReferences: Raskovic, A., Milanovic, I., Pavlovic, N., Cebovic, T., Vukmirovic, S., & Mikov, M. (2014). Analgesic effects of rosemary essential oil and its interactions with codeine and paracetamol in mice. Eur Rev Med Pharmacol Sci, 18(1), 165-172.
growingInformation: Thrives in full sun and well-drained soil. It is a perennial plant in zones 5 through 10.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves before the plant flowers for highest concentration of essential oils.

dosageInformation.adult: Add a few leaves to dishes or use 2-4 drops of diluted essential oil daily
dosageInformation.children: Use sparingly in food. Essential oil is not recommended
dosageInformation.elderly: Add a few leaves to dishes or use 1-2 drops of diluted essential oil daily

shelfLife: Fresh leaves can be stored in the fridge for up to a week. Dried oregano and essential oil can be stored for up to 3 years if properly stored
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry, dark place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with lithium, diuretics and anticoagulant drugs

name: Cayenne
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the peppers are bright red, typically 70-80 days after planting.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place.
interactionsWithMedications: Ace inhibitors
Aspirin
Blood-thinning medicines
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water with ginger for 10 minutes
Can be ground and taken as a supplement
Used as a spice in meals
cautions: Can cause irritation if handled improperly
May upset sensitive stomachs
Avoid use if you have an ulcer or other gastrointestinal conditions
Consult your doctor before use if you are pregnant or nursing

name: Guarana
uses: Used in a stamina drink to boost energy and performance, especially before exercise
Used as a natural remedy for chronic fatigue syndrome
preparationMethods: Mix guarana powder in cold water
Add honey and fresh orange juice
cautions: High in caffeine
Not recommended for children
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
Not recommended for those sensitive to caffeine

Efficacy of a Guarana (Paullinia cupana) in the treatment of chronic fatigue syndrome: a pilot study - Journal of Herbal Medicine

harvestingInformation: Seeds are harvested when the fruit splits open naturally

dosageInformation.elderly: Start with a lower dose due to potential sensitivity to caffeine

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners, antidepressants, and other stimulants like coffee. Consulting a healthcare provider is recommended before starting guarana.

name: Cordyceps
uses: Used in energy boost capsules for stamina and vitality
Used in traditional Chinese medicine for treating fatigue and boosting immune system
preparationMethods: Powder mixed with Maca powder for capsule filling
Steeping dried cordyceps in hot water to make a tonic tea
cautions: May interact with certain medications, including those for diabetes and anticoagulants
Pregnant and lactating women should consult a doctor before consumption

harvestingInformation: Harvested when the fruiting body is fully mature, usually in the late summer or early autumn

dosageInformation.children: Consult a doctor for appropriate dosage

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May potentiate the effects of anticoagulants and hypoglycemic agents

name: Ginseng (Panax ginseng)
uses: Taken as a shot in the morning for a quick energy boost and mental alertness
Used in traditional Chinese medicine to treat stress and fatigue
preparationMethods: Mix ginseng powder with warm water, lemon juice, and honey
Can be brewed as a tea or used in cooking
cautions: May cause insomnia or headaches in some individuals
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
Individuals with high blood pressure should consult their healthcare practitioner before consuming
growingInformation: Ginseng is a perennial plant that prefers cool and shady growing locations. It matures in 4-5 years.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in the fall after it has reached maturity (4-5 years). The plant's berries are also harvested for propagating new plants.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners, diabetes, and antidepressant medications

name: Holy Basil (Tulsi)
properties: Enhances mood by modulating cortisol levels
cautions: Considered safe with few known side effects
Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult with a healthcare professional before intake
May lower blood sugar levels excessively in people with diabetes
sourceReferences: Cohen MM. Tulsi - Ocimum sanctum: A herb for all reasons. J Ayurveda Integr Med. 2014;5(4):251–259. doi:10.4103/0975-9476.146554

Kumar A, Agarwal K, Maurya AK, Shanker K, Bushra U, Tandon S. Pharmacological and phytochemical evaluation of Ocimum sanctum root extracts for its antiinflammatory, analgesic and antipyretic activities. Pharmacogn Mag. 2015 Apr-Jun;11(42):217-24.
growingInformation: Thrives in warm tropical climates but can also grow in cooler climates indoors.
harvestingInformation: Should be harvested when the plant is mature, typically in the summer and early fall.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under the age of 18
dosageInformation.elderly: Consult healthcare provider for appropriate dosage

shelfLife: Dried Holy Basil lasts for 1 to 2 years, while the essential oil lasts for about 2 to 3 years.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark place. Dried Holy Basil should be stored in an air-tight container.

interactionsWithMedications.diabetes medications: May lower blood sugar levels dramatically

name: Golden Milk
growingInformation: Turmeric prefers warm, tropical climates and well-drained soil. It can be planted in spring in cooler climates.
Ashwagandha is a perennial plant that grows in dry parts of South Asia and can be planted in early summer in other climates.
Cinnamon trees are tropical plants that require high humidity and heat. The bark is harvested from mature trees.
harvestingInformation: Turmeric roots are harvested 8-10 months after planting.
Ashwagandha roots can be harvested in late fall, 5-6 months after planting.
Cinnamon bark can be harvested from trees that are at least 2 years old.
uses: Drunk in the evening for relaxation and to promote a restful night's sleep
Consumed regularly to support inflammatory conditions.
preparationMethods: Heat plant-based milk with turmeric, ashwagandha, cinnamon, and black pepper. Whisk until smooth, remove from heat, and add honey or maple syrup.
cautions: Turmeric may interact with blood-thinning medications
Ashwagandha may potentiate thyroid medications or sedatives

dosageInformation.children: Consult a medical professional before administration to children.
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 cup daily, consult a medical professional if on any medications.

shelfLife: If stored properly, the ingredients can last up to 2 years.
storageInstructions: Store the ingredients in a cool, dry, and dark place.
interactionsWithMedications: Blood-thinning medications (Turmeric)
Sedatives or thyroid medications (Ashwagandha)

name: Schisandra Berry
cautions: Consult with a healthcare provider if pregnant, breastfeeding, or on medication
growingInformation: Thrives in well-drained soil and partial to full shade
harvestingInformation: Harvest berries in late summer or early fall when they are ripe
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place and out of direct sunlight

interactions.medications: Can interfere with drug metabolism enzymes, consult healthcare provider if taking medication

name: Shatavari
uses: Used in Bone-Balancing Tea for hormone balance and bone health
Used traditionally in Ayurvedic medicine for enhancing fertility, supporting digestion, and treating menopausal symptoms
preparationMethods: Powder form can be consumed with warm water or milk
cautions: Generally safe; may have diuretic effects
Avoid during pregnancy unless under professional advice
Potentially lowers blood sugar, caution when used with diabetes medications
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained soil in full to partial shade. Tolerant of many soil types.
harvestingInformation: Roots are harvested in the autumn after the plant's third growth year.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Keep out of reach of children.

name: Gotu Kola
uses: Used in resilience tea alongside Ashwagandha to reduce fatigue
preparationMethods: Dried Gotu Kola is simmered with Ashwagandha root for tea preparation.
cautions: Not recommended for pregnant women without consulting a healthcare provider.
Consult with a doctor before use if you have liver disease.
growingInformation: Thrives in tropical wetlands and requires full sun to partial shade and moist, well-draining soil.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves throughout its growing season.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children without medical supervision.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diabetes medication
May interact with cholesterol medication
May interact with sedatives

name: Tulsi
uses: Used in a face serum for collagen production and reducing signs of aging
Used as a tea for reducing stress and relieving mild discomfort
source: Journal of Ayurveda and Integrative Medicine
growing information: Tulsi prefers rich soil with good drainage, full sun, and regular watering. Frost-sensitive.
harvesting information: Leaves and flowers can be harvested as soon as they appear. Seeds are harvested when fully matured.

dosage information.adult: 1–2 grams of dried leaves per day
dosage information.elderly: 0.5 grams of dried leaves per day

shelf life: Up to 1 year when stored properly
storage instructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from sunlight. Sealed, dark container is preferred.
interactions with medications: May interact with anti-coagulant and anti-platelet drugs

name: Yerba Mate
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water with Ginseng
Often used as an ingredient in energy drinks
cautions: Contains caffeine, which may affect sleep or cause jitteriness in some individuals
Overconsumption might lead to increased heart rate or sleep disturbances
growingInformation: Yerba Mate is a South American tree and prefers tropical or subtropical climates. It grows well in rich and well-drained soils, and prefers partial to full sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Leaves and twigs are typically harvested in spring, but can be collected year round.

dosageInformation.adult: 1 to 3 cups of brewed tea daily
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children due to caffeine content

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place in a sealed container. Keep away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May increase effects of caffeine and other stimulants
May interact with medications that slow blood clotting such as anticoagulant/antiplatelet drugs
Lithium and other mood stabilizing drugs

name: Ginkgo Biloba
uses: Improves memory and thinking in people affected by Alzheimer's or vascular dementia
preparationMethods: Used in various formulations to support eye health
Can be taken as a supplement or consumed in tea
cautions: Not recommended for children, pregnant women or people on blood-thinning medications
Can cause allergic skin reactions, digestive upset, headache and dizziness in some individuals
growingInformation: Grows in well-drained soil under full sun to partial shade
harvestingInformation: Leaves are harvested in late summer and dried for medicinal use

dosageInformation.elderly: Consult with a health care provider

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place. Keep out of reach of children
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners, antidepressants, medications for high blood pressure and diabetes

name: Beetroot
properties: High in nitrates that improve blood flow
uses: Boosts nitric oxide levels, which can help increase stamina and enhance performance
Reduces muscle soreness and promotes quicker muscle recovery after workouts, courtesy its nitrate content
preparationMethods: Mix 1/4 cup of Beetroot juice with grated Ginger and water for a Pre-Workout Tonic
cautions: Consuming large amounts might cause the urine or stool to turn pink or red
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained, sandy loam with pH of 6.2-6.8. Plant 1 cm deep in rows 30-45 cm apart. Begin thinning when seedlings are 2.5 cm tall.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when roots are between 2.5 to 5 cm in diameter. Roots larger than this can become woody.
dosageInformation: 1/4 cup of juice or 1-2 medium-sized beetroots daily for adults. Adjust dose proportionately for children and elderly based on body weight.
shelfLife: Fresh beetroots will last 2-3 weeks in refrigerator. Once opened, consume beetroot juice within 48 hours.
storageInstructions: Store fresh beetroots in a cool, dry place, or refrigerate. Keep beetroot juice refrigerated and tightly sealed after opening.
interactionsWithMedications: May lower blood pressure - caution advised for those taking blood pressure medications. Diabetics should monitor blood sugar levels, as beetroot can affect insulin levels.

name: Siberian Ginseng
cautions: May cause insomnia
High blood pressure in sensitive individuals
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Prefers a shaded and cool environment. Requires rich and well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the roots in the autumn of the 4th or 5th year of growth.
shelfLife: 2-3 years in a dry, cool place
storageInstructions: Store in a sealed container away from heat and direct sunlight.

interactions.medications: May interact with anticoagulants, corticosteroids, and drugs for diabetes and high blood pressure.

name: Cacao
preparationMethods: Powder mixed into warm almond milk with Maca
Roasted and ground for use in baking or beverages
cautions: Contains caffeine and theobromine, which may cause jitteriness or sleep disturbances
People with allergies to chocolate should avoid cacao
Excessive consumption can cause digestive discomfort
sourceReferences: Arts IC, Hollman PC, Kromhout D. 'Chocolate as a source of tea flavonoids.' Lancet. 1999;354(9177):488
Aprotosoaie AC, Miron A, Trifan A, Luca VS, Costache II. 'The Cardiovascular Effects of Cocoa Polyphenols—An Overview.' Diseases. 2016;4(4):39
growingInformation: Cacao prefers a hot, humid climate and a rainfall of 60 to 100 inches per year. It grows well under canopy shade.
harvestingInformation: Fruit is harvested when ripe, typically where the color changes from green to yellow or red. Seeds are extracted and fermented for several days.

dosageInformation.elderly: Start with a smaller dose and adjust based on tolerance

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: Cacao may decrease how quickly the liver metabolizes certain medications, potentially increasing their effects and side effects
Pregnant and breastfeeding women are advised to limit their consumption due to the caffeine content

name: Oatstraw
preparationMethods: Commonly prepared as a tea or infusion
Can also be used in poultices or tinctures
cautions: Generally considered safe, but it's advisable to consult with a healthcare provider for long-term use
Do not use if you have celiac disease or gluten intolerance
May cause bloating or gas in some individuals
sourceReferences: The National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Prefers full sun and rich, well-drained soil. Can tolerate cool climates.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in mid to late summer when the grain is still milky.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May increase the effects of anti-anxiety medications

name: Matcha Green Tea
uses: Used for a natural energy boost
preparationMethods: Whisk matcha powder into hot water until frothy, then add raw honey if desired
cautions: May contain caffeine; avoid consuming in large amounts or late in the day to prevent sleep disturbances
growingInformation: In a shaded location with well-drained, fertile soil. It requires annual average temperatures around 15-20 degree Celsius.
harvestingInformation: Usually harvested between May and June, using young leaves which are carefully shaded from the sun about 20-30 days before harvest to increase chlorophyll levels and produce fine flavour.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 18 years due to caffeine content
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 cup daily or as advised by a healthcare professional

storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container, in a cool, dark place, away from direct sunlight and moisture
interactionsWithMedications: Can interfere with iron absorption if consumed within 1 hour before or after taking iron supplements
May increase the effect of stimulant drugs

name: Damiana
preparationMethods: Steep dried damiana leaves in hot water for 15 minutes, strain, then add lemon juice and honey to taste
cautions: Consult with a healthcare provider before use, especially if pregnant, nursing, or on medication
May cause low blood sugar in some individuals
growingInformation: Damiana is a subtropical plant that thrives in well-drained soils, full sun and with moderate water.
harvestingInformation: Leaves and stems should be harvested during summer and dried for future use.

dosageInformation.adult: Typically, 2 to 4 grams of dried herb brewed into tea daily
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with low dose and increase if needed under health provider's guidance

shelfLife: Dried damiana herb can be kept for up to a year if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in a sealed container to protect it from light and moisture

name: Cat’s Claw
cautions: May interact with certain medications and is not recommended for pregnant women
May cause dizziness in some individuals
growingInformation: Tropical vine, prefers humid, warm conditions. Can be propagated from cuttings or seeds.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the bark and root in late spring or early summer.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from light.
interactions: May interact with medications that slow blood clotting, immune suppressants, and antihypertensive drugs.

name: Goji Berry
cautions: May interact with blood-thinners and diabetes medications
interactions: Anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs
Hypoglycemics
growingInformation: Well-drained soil
Full sun to partial shade
JWater moderately
harvestingInformation: When the berries reach full color
Do not touch the berries directly. Shake onto a sheet or use gloves.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place

name: Mugwort
uses: Consumed before bedtime to enhance dream clarity and support restful sleep
Used in traditional medicine to relieve digestive complaints such as constipation, diarrhea, cramps, and bloating
preparationMethods: Steep 1 teaspoon dried mugwort (and peppermint for added benefits) in 1 cup hot water for 10 minutes, then strain before drinking

dosageInformation.elderly: Same as adult dosage but monitor for heightened sensitivity

Can aid in reducing digestive disorders.

cautions: Rare, but may cause skin irritation or nausea.

harvestingInformation: Leaves and stems should be harvested in summer before it flowers.
