dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years of age

shelfLife: Dried leaves will remain potent for up to 1 year.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dark place.

interactions.medications: May interact with painkillers and anti-inflammatory drugs.

sourceReferences: Journal of Agriculture and Food Chemistry, 2007

name: Kava Kava
preparationMethods: Mix 1 teaspoon dried kava root powder in 1 cup warm water until dissolved
Add 1 teaspoon raw honey and stir well
growingInformation: Tropical conditions preferable. Requires well-drained soil and temperatures above 68 F (20 C).
harvestingInformation: Typically harvested at 3-4 years of age when root yields are at their maximum.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Store in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMedications: Can interact with other medications including sedatives and certain psychiatric medications. Consult your doctor before using.
cautions: May cause liver damage if used in large amounts or for extended periods
Not recommended for use with alcohol or other medications that affect the liver

name: Valerian Root
preparationMethods: Typically used in tea blends for its calming effects
Can be taken as capsules for insomnia
cautions: May cause drowsiness
Not recommended before operating heavy machinery
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Valerian is a perennial plant native to Europe and Asia. It prefers full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in the fall of second year.
activeConstituents: Valerenic acid, isovaleric acid, and a variety of antioxidants

dosageInformation.adults: 250mg to 600mg of dried root, 30-60 minutes before bedtime. Lower dose during daytime.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May increase the effects of sedative and anti-anxiety medications. Check with your doctor if you're taking these.

name: Chamomile and Lavender
sourceReferences: ScienceDirect - Chamomile: Assessed by Clinical Trials
NCBI - Effect of lavender scent inhalation on prevention of stress, anxiety, and depression
harvestingInformation: Harvest when flowers are fully open in dry weather, mid-morning after dew has evaporated

dosageInformation.adult: 1 to 3 cups of tea per day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: Chamomile may interact with blood thinning medications
Lavender may enhance the sedative effects of CNS depressants
preparationMethods: Tea made by steeping dried chamomile flowers and lavender buds in hot water, then strained and sweetened with honey if desired
cautions: Chamomile may cause allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to the Asteraceae/Compositae family. Lavender used in large amounts may cause sedation

name: Extraction Techniques
properties: Can extract volatile oils, vitamins, and delicate compounds from leaves, flowers, and soft plant parts
Can use prolonged boiling to extract medicinal properties from tough plant materials like roots, barks, and seeds
Alcohol or vinegar-based extracts that preserve and concentrate the active compounds of herbs
Glycerin-based extracts suitable for those avoiding alcohol, preserving and extracting active compounds
Herbs infused in oil to extract lipid-soluble compounds, used topically or in cooking
uses: Used to extract medicinal properties from various parts of the plants
Can be used topically or in cooking, depending on the technique
sourceReferences: Bown. D. (1995). Encyclopedia of Herbs and their Uses. Dorling Kindersley, London. 424
Chevallier. A. (1996). The Encyclopedia of Medicinal Plants Dorling Kindersley. London 9
historicalContext: The extraction of medicinal compounds from herbs and plants has been a practice employed by civilizations around the world for thousands of years, from ancient Egypt and China, to Greek and Roman societies, and into the modern age.
culturalSignificance: These techniques remain a significant part of herbal medicine in cultures worldwide. In some communities, they are integral part of the local healthcare system.
modernApplications: Today, these extraction techniques are utilized not only in homemade remedies and artisanal products, but also in the manufacture of commercial herbal supplements and skincare products.

name: Cinnamon Bark
properties: ability to regulate blood sugar levels
uses: Application as a warming herb in cold conditions
cautions: High doses can be toxic
May interact with blood thinners and diabetes medication
growingInformation: Cinnamon trees grow in tropical regions with heavy rainfall and prefer rich, well-drained soil. They require hot, humid conditions and partial or full sun exposure. They are usually grown from seeds and take about 3 years to reach maturity.
harvestingInformation: Cinnamon bark is harvested from the trees when they are around 2 years old. The outer bark is stripped off and the inner bark is left to dry in rolls, which forms the characteristic cinnamon sticks.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 2 years. For age 2-6, max 0.5 g/day; for age 6-12, max 2g/day
dosageInformation.elderly: 1-2 g/day, or as advised by healthcare provider

shelfLife: When stored properly, dried cinnamon bark can last up to 3 years
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Cinnamon may interact with anticoagulants, diabetes medications, liver disease medications
sourceReferences: Cinnamon: Potential Role in the Prevention of Insulin Resistance, Metabolic Syndrome, and Type 2 Diabetes, Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology

name: Andrographis
properties: Reduces severity and duration of colds and flu
uses: Drunk at the first sign of cold or flu symptoms
Used for treating digestive disorders and liver diseases
Applied to wounds and skin infections to promote healing
growingInformation: Indigenous to South Asian countries. Prefers sunny, well-drained conditions. Grows well in poor, sandy soil.
harvestingInformation: Harvested when the plant is mature, typically in autumn. The leaves and stems are used.

dosageInformation.adult: 400mg of Andrographis extract taken three times daily
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years

storageInstructions.driedHerb: Store in a cool, dark, dry place, away from heat and light
storageInstructions.tincture: Store in a cool, dark place. Keep out of reach of children

interactionsWithMedications: May interact with medications that suppress the immune system, anticoagulants, and hypotensive drugs
preparationMethods: Tea made by steeping dried andrographis leaves in hot water, then adding honey and lemon juice
cautions: May cause allergic reactions and interact with medications that affect the immune system

name: Tea Tree
uses: Used in hand wash to enhance antimicrobial effectiveness.
Can be used as adjunctive therapy to treat acne due to its anti-inflammatory properties.
Protection against insect bites and stings due to its insect repellant nature.
preparationMethods: As an essential oil in hand wash.
Mixed with carrier oils for skincare regime.
Combined with other oils in a diffuser for aromatherapy.
extractionMethod: Steam distilled from leaves and branches of the Melaleuca alternifolia tree.
dilutionRatios: Generally, for every 1 to 2 drops of essential oil, 12 drops of a carrier oil should be used.
safetyPrecautions: May cause skin irritation in some individuals; patch test before widespread use.
Not to be ingested orally.
Avoid contact with eyes, inner ears, and sensitive areas.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from sunlight and heat.
cautions: May cause skin irritation in some individuals; patch test before widespread use.

name: Astragalus Root
uses: Drunk as a tea for long-term immune support, especially during cold and flu season
Used in traditional Chinese medicine to aid digestion and boost metabolism
preparationMethods: Tea made by simmering dried astragalus root in water for 20-30 minutes
cautions: May interact with medications that suppress the immune system
Contact your health care provider before starting astragalus if you are pregnant, nursing, or have an autoimmune disease
growingInformation: Requires full sun; prefers well-draining soil; hardy to -30 degrees F.
harvestingInformation: Harvest roots in the fall of the third or fourth year.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Immunosuppressant drugs
Anticoagulants

name: Garlic and Honey
properties: Combines soothing and immune-supporting effects of honey.
uses: Taken for immune support when experiencing cold or flu symptoms.
Beneficial in reducing the severity of upper respiratory infections.
preparationMethods: Infusion made by covering peeled garlic cloves with raw honey and letting it sit for 1-2 weeks.
cautions: Garlic can interact with certain medications, including blood thinners.
Excessive consumption can lead to heartburn or digestive issues.
growingInformation: Garlic prefers cool weather and is typically planted in the fall. Honey is produced by bees from nectar of flowers.
harvestingInformation: Garlic is harvested in late summer or early fall. Honey harvest typically occurs between spring and fall.
activeConstituents: Garlic contains allicin, amino acids, and S-allyl cysteine. Honey primarily consists of sugars like fructose and glucose, and contains small amounts of proteins, enzymes, amino acids, minerals, trace elements, vitamins, aroma compounds and polyphenols.
shelfLife: Up to 1 year if stored correctly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Ensure the jar is tightly sealed.
interactionsWithMedications: Blood thinners
HIV drugs
Isoniazid (used to treat tuberculosis)

name: Ginger and Turmeric Golden Milk
uses: Drunk daily, preferably in the evening, for immune health and inflammation reduction
promotes restful sleep due to its soothing ingredients
sourceReferences: Jayashree, G., & Kurup Muraleedhara, G., (2018). Clinically validated anti-inflammatory effects of turmeric. Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology, 995, 65-83. DOI: 10.1007/978-981-10-6583-5_3
Bode, A. M., & Dong, Z., (2011). The Amazing and Mighty Ginger. Herbal Medicine: Biomolecular and Clinical Aspects. 2nd edition.
growingInformation: Both ginger and turmeric are tropical plants that prefer warm, humid conditions and well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: The roots can be harvested 8-10 months after planting.
dosageInformation: 1-2 cups daily (adults)
Consult doctor for children and elderly dosage
shelfLife: Prepared golden milk lasts for 2-3 days when refrigerated
storageInstructions: Store in airtight jar in the fridge
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood-thinning medications
May interfere with drugs that reduce stomach acid
preparationMethods: Heated coconut milk mixed with turmeric, ginger, cinnamon, black pepper, and honey
cautions: Turmeric can interact with blood-thinning medications

name: Tulsi and Lemon Balm
growingInfo: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil
harvestingInfo: Leaves can be harvested at any point during the growing season. For best flavor, harvest in the morning.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight
uses: Drunk as a tea for immune support and stress reduction
preparationMethods: Tea made by steeping dried tulsi and lemon balm leaves in hot water, then adding honey
cautions: May interact with sedatives and other medications
Consult healthcare provider before use if pregnant, nursing, or taking any medications
sourceReferences: Modern Essentials: A Contemporary Guide to the Therapeutic Use of Essential Oils
Herbal Medicine: Biomolecular and Clinical Aspects
interactions: May increase effects of sedatives

name: Fire Cider Tonic
preparationMethods: Combine ingredients like apple cider vinegar, horseradish, ginger, garlic, cayenne pepper, and honey in a jar for 4-6 weeks.
cautions: Not recommended for those who are allergic to any of the ingredients
Ensure to dilute before intake
shelfLife: Up to 12 months when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place. Shake well before use.
interactionWithMedications: May interact with blood-thinners and certain heart medications

name: Oregano Oil
uses: Used for immune support and to inhibit viral replication, particularly during acute viral infections
Can be applied topically to treat skin infections and irritations when diluted properly.
cautions: Should be used with caution internally and for short-term treatment due to its potency
Avoid contact with eyes and mucus membranes.
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women.
sourceReferences: Dr. Axe. (2019). 'Oregano Oil Benefits for Infections, Fungus & Even the Common Cold.'
Healthline. (2020).'The Top 11 Benefits of Oregano Oil.'

dilutionRatios.Topical use: 1 part oregano oil to 3 parts carrier oil
dilutionRatios.Internal use: Dilute 1 drop in 4 oz of water

safetyPrecautions: Do not use undiluted on the skin or in the eyes.
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place with the lid tightly sealed.

name: Rosehip
growingInformation: Thrives in well-drained soil, full sun or partial shade. Hardy in winter.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in fall or after the first frost when fruit turns bright red.
activeConstituents: Vitamins (C, E, B and A), flavonoids, carotenoids, polyphenols
shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in airtight containers, out of direct light and humidity
interactionsWithMedications: Possible interaction with anticoagulant drugs, consult your doctor
preparationMethods: Steep with blueberries in hot water for 15 minutes, strain and serve warm
cautions: None mentioned
Consult healthcare provider if pregnant, breastfeeding or on medication

name: Elderflower
uses: Used in an eye compress with Chamomile to relieve puffiness
Consumed as a tea for its anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water, then used to soak cotton pads
Can be brewed into a tea or infused in oil
cautions: Generally considered safe, but always test for allergic reactions
Avoid if pregnant or breastfeeding as there's insufficient reliable data
sourceReferences: Chevallier, Andrew. Encyclopedia of Herbal Medicine. New York, NY: DK Publishing, 2016.
Braun, Lesley & Cohen, Marc. Herbs & Natural Supplements. An Evidence-Based Guide, Vol 2. Australia: Churchill Livingstone, 2014.
growingInformation: Elderflowers thrive in full sun or partial shade and moist, fertile soil.
harvestingInformation: Flowers are harvested in late spring or early summer and should be dried quickly to preserve their potency.

dosageInformation.adults: 2-4 grams of dried elderflowers as a tea, up to 3 times a day
dosageInformation.children: Dosage should be adjusted according to weight
dosageInformation.elderly: Same dosage as for adults but monitor for any sensitivity

shelfLife: Dried elderflowers remain potent for up to a year when stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMedications: Can enhance the effect of diuretic and laxative medications. Consult your healthcare practitioner before use if you're on these medications.

name: Sage
uses: Used in a tea to enhance bone density and hormonal health
Can be applied as a poultice to reduce inflammation
As an essential oil, can be used in aromatherapy for calming effects
preparationMethods: Steep 1 tablespoon dried Sage in 2 cups hot water for 15 minutes
Used as essential oil in diffusers or topically when appropriately diluted
cautions: Excessive consumption can lead to dry mouth and throat
Consult with a healthcare provider before using Sage if pregnant or nursing
growing_information: Sage prefers sunny locations, well-drained soil, and thrives in hardiness zones 5-9.
harvesting_information: Harvest just before or at the time of flowering. Harvest in the morning after the dew has evaporated.
shelf_life: One to two years stored dry and out of the sun
storage_instructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight
interactions: May interact with sedative medications, diabetes medications

name: Propolis and Honey Throat Spray
preparationMethods: Mix propolis tincture, raw honey, and warm water, transfer to a spray bottle
cautions: Check for allergies to bee products before use
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
growingInformation: N/A
harvestingInformation: Propolis is harvested from beehives
activeConstituents: Flavonoids, phenolics, and various types of acid

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 sprays every 2 hours or as needed
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 spray every 3 hours or as needed

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs

name: Yarrow and Peppermint Fever-Reducing Tea
preparationMethods: Steep dried yarrow and peppermint in hot water, strain, and serve warm.
cautions: Yarrow can be allergenic to some; avoid if allergic to ragweed. Peppermint may worsen acid reflux in some individuals.
Do not consume during pregnancy or breastfeeding
Do not exceed recommended dosage
sourceReferences: The Healing Power of Herbs: The Enlightened Person's Guide to the Wonders of Medicinal Plants, 1998, Michael T. Murray N.D.
growingInformation: prefer well-drained soil and full sun (both)
best to plant in early spring, after the last frost (both)
harvestingInformation: best harvested in late spring/summer (Yarrow)
best harvested just before flowering (Peppermint)
storageInstructions: store in a cool, dark place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: may interact with antacids and medications for acid reflux (Peppermint)
may interact with blood thinners (Yarrow)

name: Maitake Mushroom Immunity Soup
preparationMethods: Simmer maitake mushrooms, vegetable broth, ginger, and garlic.
Add miso paste and green onions before serving.
cautions: Miso paste is high in sodium; consume in moderation if monitoring sodium intake.
People with mushroom allergies should avoid maitake mushroom.

harvestingInformation.maturityIndicators: When the fruiting body is fully developed and caps begin to curl under

shelfLife: Dried mushrooms can last up to a year if stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dark, and dry place.
interactionsWithMedication: May decrease effectiveness of immunosuppressive drugs

name: Chaga Mushroom and Cacao Elixir
preparationMethods: Steep chaga powder in hot water
cautions: Consult with a healthcare provider if you have a mushroom allergy
or are taking medication
as chaga can interact with some medications
sourceReferences: Chen, P., Yong, Y., Gu, Y., Wang, Z., Zhang, S., Lu, L., ... & Ye, J. (2022). Antitumor and immunomodulatory effects of polysaccharides from broken-spore of Ganoderma lucidum. Frontiers in Pharmacology, 3, 135.

growingInformation.habitat: Birch trees, in colder regions like Northern Europe, Siberia, Russia, Korea, Northern Canada and Alaska.
growingInformation.cultivation: Chaga mushrooms are not easy to cultivate and are usually wild harvested.

harvestingInformation: Harvested manually from the wild during late fall to early spring, when the nutrients are at their peak.
activeConstituents: Polysaccharides, Beta-D-Glucans, Polyphenols, Triterpenes, Sterols, Melanins and Vitamins.

dosageInformation.children: Consult a healthcare provider before use

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Chaga may lower blood sugar and may cause additional effects with diabetes medications. It might also affect the immune system and interfere with medications for auto-immune diseases.

name: Black Seed Oil Immune Booster
preparationMethods: Mix black seed oil with raw honey.
cautions: Black seed oil can interact with medication and may not be suitable for pregnant women.
sourceReferences: Salem, M.L., Hossain, M.S., 2000. Protective effect of black seed oil from Nigella sativa against murine cytomegalovirus infection. International Journal of Immunopharmacology. 22(9), 729-740.

Ahmad, A., Husain, A., Mujeeb, M., Khan, S.A., Najmi, A.K., Siddique, N.A., Damanhouri, Z.A., Anwar, F., 2013. A review on therapeutic potential of Nigella sativa: A miracle herb. Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Biomedicine. 3(5), 337-352.
dilutionRatios: 1:1 ratio with a carrier oil for topical use. Do not exceed 1 teaspoon for internal use.
carrierOilRecommendations: Olive oil, coconut oil, and jojoba oil.
safetyPrecautions: Avoid contact with eyes. In case of allergy, discontinue use. It may lower blood sugar levels and should be used with caution in people with diabetes.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from heat and light

name: Thyme and Sage Herbal Gargle
uses: Used traditionally to soothe sore throats
Frequently used to fight bacterial and viral infections
preparationMethods: Steep thyme and sage in boiling water for ten minutes, add a teaspoon of sea salt, cool before gargling.
partsUsed: Leaves of both Thyme and Sage
growingInformation: Thyme and Sage both prefer full sun and well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest in midsummer just before the plant flowers

dosageInformation.children: only use sage under pediatrician's guidance

shelfLife: Sage lasts two to three years, Thyme lasts up to five years
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry, and dark place
interactionsWithMedications: Sage can interact with diabetes drugs, seisure control drugs, sedative medications and drugs involved in hormone therapy
cautions: Sage should be used cautiously by nursing mothers as it can reduce milk supply.
Consult healthcare provider before using these herbs if pregnant or breastfeeding, or if you have a medical condition or are taking any medication.
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health

name: Marshmallow Root and Licorice Throat Soother
preparationMethods: Steep marshmallow and licorice roots in hot water for 10-15 minutes
cautions: Licorice root can elevate blood pressure if consumed in large quantities over a long period.
sourceReferences: The Herbal Apothecary: 100 Medicinal Herbs and How to Use Them, JJ Pursell
growInfo: These herbs prefer rich, damp areas and full sun or partial shade. Marshmallow plants are winter hardy and licorice plants are perennial in zones 7 and warmer.
harvestInfo: Roots should be harvested in the fall after the plants have gone to seed.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactions: Licorice root may interact with certain medications, including diuretics, corticosteroids, or heart medications.

name: Elderflower and Linden Cold Relief Tea
uses: Promotes good sleep due to its calming effect
preparationMethods: Steep elderflower and linden in hot water
cautions: Elderflower is generally safe, but care should be taken as the raw plant contains toxic substances that are removed during cooking or drying
Individuals allergic to flowers from the Tiliaceae family should avoid linden.
Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult their doctors before consumption.

growingInformation.Elderflower: Prefers full sun and moist, well-drained soil.
growingInformation.Linden: Grows in well-drained soil, full sun to partial shade.

harvestingInformation.Elderflower: Harvest in late spring or early summer when in full bloom.
harvestingInformation.LIinden: Harvest in early summer when flowers open.

storageInstructions: Store in a sealed container, in a cool, dark, and dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Elderflower might lower blood sugar levels and could interfere with diabetes medications. Linden might act as a diuretic and could interfere with diuretic medications.

name: Linden
cautions: Rarely, may cause heart damage if consumed in excessive quantities
Pregnant women should avoid
growingInformation: In cooler climates, needs full sun. Prefers well-drained, loamy soil. Pruning needed for the health of the tree.
harvestingInformation: Harvest flowers in spring and early summer, leaves can be harvested throughout the summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 2-4 grams of flowers for tea or 4-5 tablespoons per day
dosageInformation.children: For children under 12, half the adult dosage is recommended
dosageInformation.elderly: Same as adult dosage, unless directed otherwise by a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Up to 1 year when stored properly
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark, and dry place. Make sure it is sealed well.
interactions: May intensify the effects of sedative medications

name: Clove
uses: Used in a tincture to alleviate muscle pain and tension headaches
Employed in dental care remedies to relieve toothache
preparationMethods: Combined with Peppermint in alcohol to create a tension relief tincture
Made into a paste with water applied on the affected tooth to treat toothache
cautions: May irritate the skin and mucous membranes; use with caution
Should not be used by people with bleeding disorders, or prior to surgery
growingInformation: Clove is a tropical plant that prefers a hot, humid climate and rich soil with good drainage
harvestingInformation: Clove flower buds are hand-picked when they are fully grown yet unopened, then dried in the sun for 2-3 days

dosageInformation.adults: For tincture: 20-30 drops, 2-3 times daily in a glass of water
dosageInformation.elderly: 10-15 drops, 2-3 times daily in a glass of water

shelfLife: Whole cloves can last up to a year, while ground clove has a shelf-life of 3-4 months if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in an air-tight container in a cool, dark place
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulants
Antiplatelet drugs
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

name: Black Pepper
uses: Combined with Turmeric for anti-inflammatory effects
cautions: Excessive consumption may lead to gastrointestinal irritation
growingInformation: Grows in hot, humid climates. Requires well-drained soil and partial sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the peppercorns when they are still green. Dry under the sun until they shrivel and turn black.

dosageInformation.adults: No more than 20 mg per day
dosageInformation.elderly: No more than 10 mg per day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinning medications and drugs metabolized by the liver.
sourceReferences: Shoba G, et al. Influence of piperine on the pharmacokinetics of curcumin in animals and human volunteers. Planta Med. 1998;64(4):353-356.
Srinivasan K. Black pepper and its pungent principle-piperine: a review of diverse physiological effects. Crit Rev Food Sci Nutr. 2007;47(8):735-748.

name: Yellow Dock Root
cautions: May cause mild side effects such as diarrhea
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Herbal Medicine: Biomolecular and Clinical Aspects by Iris F.F. Benzie and Sissi Wachtel-Galor
growingInformation: Yellow Dock is a perennial weed native to Europe but now found throughout North America and parts of Western Asia. It prefers sunny locations and rich, moist soil.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in late fall or early spring when the plant is in dormancy. Leaves are picked when they're young and tender.

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 grams of dried root three times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Keep out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: May impact absorption of drugs due to high tannin content

name: Osha Root
preparationMethods: Simmered in water to make a tea
cautions: Not well studied in pregnant or nursing women; use caution
Allergic reactions are rare, but possible
sourceReferences: Herbal Medicine: Expanded Commission E Monographs
growingInformation: Grows best in moist, well-drained soil. It is naturally found at high elevations in the Rocky Mountains.
harvestingInformation: The root is harvested in the fall after the plant has matured.

dosageInformation.adult: Dried root: 1 to 2 grams up to three times a day
dosageInformation.children: Should not be given to children without professional advice
dosageInformation.elderly: Dose may need to be reduced for individuals over 65 due to decreased metabolism

shelfLife: Can be stored for up to three years in ideal conditions
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diuretics and medication for high blood pressure

name: Schisandra
uses: Part of a stress-relief tea to enhance recovery
preparationMethods: Simmered with Reishi mushroom in water
cautions: May cause gastrointestinal upset in some individuals
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should avoid use
growingInformation: Prefers partial to full shade and moist, well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Berries are harvested when fully ripened, usually in late summer or early fall.
shelfLife: Two to three years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulants
Sedatives

name: Yarrow
preparationMethods: can be brewed as a tea
cautions: May cause photosensitivity; avoid direct sunlight after application
Pregnant women should avoid contact
Excessive intake can cause drowsiness
growingInformation: Grows best in full sun and well-drained soil. Suitable for USDA zones 3-9.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the flowers when fully open, usually around late spring to early summer.

dosageInformation.adult: Infused oil: Use topically 2-3 times a day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place, ideally in a glass container
interactions: Avoid concomitant use with sedative medications due to possible additive effects

name: Maitake Mushroom
growingInformation: Maitake mushroom is a perennial fungus that grows naturally on the dead trunks of oak trees. It prefers a temperate and humid climate.
harvestingInformation: Maitake mushrooms are harvested in late summer to early autumn. They are cut at the base of the mushroom cluster.
shelfLife: Can be kept fresh for up to a week in the refrigerator. Dried maitake mushrooms can last for up to a year.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place. Fresh maitake should be stored in the refrigerator.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diabetes and blood-thinning medications
cautions: May interact with diabetes and blood-thinning medications

name: Horseradish
growingInformation: Horseradish requires sunlight and well drained soil. It's a hardy perennial plant that can become invasive if not controlled.
harvestingInformation: Harvest horseradish roots in late fall or early spring. Use a shovel or spade to dig deep and lift the root from the soil.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 4. For older children, reduce adult dosage by half.
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with smaller dosages, as the body might be more sensitive to its effects

shelfLife: Horseradish roots can last for up to three months in the refrigerator if unwashed and stored in a plastic bag. Prepared horseradish should be consumed within 3 to 4 weeks after opening.
storageInstructions: Store roots at a temperature below 30°F with high humidity to prevent them from becoming woody. Keep prepared horseradish in a tightly sealed jar in the refrigerator.
interactionsWithMedications: Horseradish may increase the risk of bleeding when taken with blood thinners such as warfarin. It may also interfere with the absorption of certain thyroid medications.
preparationMethods: Mixed with other ingredients to make a tonic
cautions: May irritate the stomach lining or mucous membranes.
Consume in moderation as it can cause allergic reactions or drug interactions

name: Hyssop
uses: Used in treatment of digestive problems
preparationMethods: Dried steeped in hot water with mullein and optionally sweetened with honey.
As an essential oil in aromatherapy.
cautions: Should be avoided by pregnant women
Can cause seizures if consumed in excess
growingInformation: Grows best in full sun in well-drained soil. Tolerates poor soil and drought.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in late summer before the plants flower for best medicinal quality.

dosageInformation.adults: 2-3 g of dried hyssop steeped in boiling water 3 times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry location in a sealed container.
interactions: Avoid taking with medications that cause drowsiness or slow your breathing.

name: Goldenseal
uses: Combined with Eyebright in eye drops for irritated eyes
Used in creams for skin disorders and rashes
preparationMethods: Simmered with Eyebright and strained for eye drops
Applied topically when mixed into creams
cautions: Can interact with certain medications and is not recommended during pregnancy
Avoid usage if allergic to any plants in the Ranunculaceae family
growingInformation: Prefers partially shaded, moist, well-drained soils.
harvestingInformation: Harvested in the fall after the plant's foliage has died back.

dosageInformation.adult: Generally, 1-2 grams of dried goldenseal can be infused in tea.
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children without doctor’s advice.
dosageInformation.elderly: Most professionals recommend conservative doses, no more than 2 grams per day.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Keep out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: Can interact with medications, including those for high blood pressure and blood thinners.

name: Propolis
uses: Effective against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
Used for respiratory and oral infections
cautions: People with allergies to bee products or severe allergies should use with caution
growingInformation: Produced by bees using tree and plant resins
harvestingInformation: Harvested by beekeepers from the frames and hives of bees

dosageInformation.adult: 100-300mg daily for general immune support, higher doses depend on specific conditions
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 1 year. Older children should use smaller doses than adults

storageInstructions: Store in cool, dry place away from direct light
interactionsMedications: May slow blood clotting. People on anticoagulant or antiplatelet drugs should use with caution.

name: Chaga Mushroom
growingInfo: Chaga mushroom grows predominantly on birch trees in cold climates like Siberia, northern Canada, Alaska, and Northern parts of United States. It takes several years to mature.
harvestingInfo: Harvested in the wild, usually in the fall season, and only from living trees.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place
interactions: Potential interactions with insulin or blood-thinning medications

name: Black Seed Oil
uses: May aid in maintaining healthy blood pressure
preparationMethods: Mixed with raw honey to create an anti-inflammatory tonic
Can be used topically when diluted with a carrier oil
cautions: While generally safe, it's important to use in moderation and be aware of potential allergic reactions
Pregnant women should not use black seed oil without consulting a healthcare professional
extractionMethod: Cold pressing of Nigella sativa seeds
dilutionRatios: 1-2% essential oil in a carrier oil for topical usage
safetyPrecautions: Supportive care is needed in case of ingestion. Avoid contact with eyes. Store out of reach of children. If pregnant or under a doctor’s care, consult physician.
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dry, and dark place. Keep bottle tightly closed to prevent evaporation and protect the oil from oxidation

name: Onion
uses: Used in cough syrups for its expectorant properties
Used in cooking for flavor enhancement and health benefits
preparationMethods: Boiled in water for tea or soup
cautions: Generally safe, but raw onion can cause digestive discomfort in some
High consumption may contribute to heartburn or gastric irritation
growingInformation: Onions are best grown in full sun and well-drained soil. They are usually planted in early spring and harvested in late summer to early autumn.
harvestingInformation: Harvest onions when the tops have fallen over and turned yellow or brown.

dosageInformation.adult: Generally safe in food amounts. For medicinal use, consult a healthcare provider.
dosageInformation.children: Safe in children in food amounts. For medicinal use, consult a healthcare provider.
dosageInformation.elderly: Generally safe in food amounts. For medicinal use, consult a healthcare provider.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, well-ventilated area. Avoid storing with potatoes as they promote sprouting.

interactionsWithMedications.Warfarin (Coumadin): Onion might increase the risk of bleeding in people taking warfarin

name: Apple Cider Vinegar
purityRequirements: Organic, raw, unfiltered apple cider vinegar with the 'mother'
sourcingInformation: Available in supermarkets or health stores
uses: Used in a sinus tonic for sinus relief and immune support
Used as a detoxifying agent in certain diets
preparationMethods: Combined with garlic, ginger, lemon juice, and cayenne pepper, stored for 1-2 weeks, shaken daily, strained, and stored in a glass bottle
dosageInformation: For sinus relief: Dilute 1 tablespoon in a cup of water and drink daily
For detox: Dilute 1-2 teaspoons in a cup of water and drink daily
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place
cautions: May cause digestive discomfort if consumed in large amounts
May interact with certain medications

name: Osha
uses: Used in a cough syrup to soothe coughs.
Used as an herbal tea for respiratory ailments.
preparationMethods: Combined with wild cherry bark and water, boiled, simmered, strained, reduced, and honey added.
cautions: None specified
Avoid during pregnancy and breastfeeding due to lack of research.
sourceReferences: Sawyer, M.F. (2003). The American Indian Osha: facts and fiction.
Moore, M. (1993). Medicinal Plants of the Mountain West.
growingInformation: Prefers mountainous, dry, well-drained conditions. Difficult to cultivate.
harvestingInformation: Roots are harvested in the fall.

dosageInformation.adult: Typically 1-2 grams dried root per day, in tea or tincture.
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children due to lack of research.
dosageInformation.elderly: Dose as per adult, but seek advice of a healthcare professional first.

shelfLife: Dried root can last up to 3 years if stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: No known interactions, but consult your healthcare provider before use if you are on any medications.

name: Wild Cherry Bark
uses: Used in combination with osha root in a cough syrup to soothe coughs.
Helps to clear mucus from the chest
preparationMethods: Combined with osha root and water, boiled, simmered, strained, reduced, and honey added.
cautions: Avoid excessive consumption and prolonged use.
sourceReferences: Traditional Medicinals Guide, 2nd Edition, National Herbalists Association of Australia
Healing Plants: An Introduction to the Healing Power of Plants, Richard Brown, 2016
growingInformation: Thrives in well-drained, fertile soil under full sun. Hardy in USDA zones 3-9.
harvestingInformation: Bark is best harvested in spring, when sap is rising, avoiding damage to the trunk.
activeConstituents: Prunasin, p-coumaric acid, benzoic acid, quercetin

dosageInformation.adult: 2-4 ml of tincture three times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: Adjust dose based on health and weight, consult a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Up to 3 years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Keep dried bark in an airtight container, in a cool, dry, dark place.
medicationInteractions: May interact with sedatives and respiratory medications

name: Horehound and Licorice Root
preparationMethods: Cough drops: Simmer dried horehound and licorice root in water, then add honey and allow the mixture to thicken before pouring into molds
cautions: Licorice root may raise blood pressure if consumed in large amounts or over a prolonged period of time. Avoid if you have hypertension, heart disease, or kidney disease.
sourceReferences: Herbal Medicine: Expanded Commission E Monographs

growingInformation.Licorice root: Full sun, rich and moist soil

storageInstructions: Store in airtight containers, in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight

interactionsWithMedications.Licorice root: May interact with corticosteroids, insulin, laxatives, and blood pressure medications

name: Fenugreek and Thyme
preparationMethods: steep with thyme in hot water for 10-15 minutes
cautions: Pregnant women should avoid consuming large quantities
People with allergy to plants in the Fabaceae family
sourceReferences: Plants used in Traditional Persian Medicine - University of Tehran.

growingInformation.Fenugreek: Prefers full sunlight with adequate watering. Suitable for container gardening.
growingInformation.Thyme: Ideal in sunny spots with well-drained soil. Can be grown indoors by a sunny window.

harvestingInformation.Fenugreek: Seeds are ready to harvest when the pods turn yellow.
harvestingInformation.Thyme: Leaves can be picked anytime. They're most flavoursome just before flowers open.

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 teaspoons of blend per cup of water, 3 times a day
dosageInformation.children: 1/2-1 teaspoon of blend per cup of water, 2 times a day
dosageInformation.elderly: 1/2-1 teaspoon of blend per cup of water, 2 times a day

storageInstructions: Store in airtight containers in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Can interfere with blood thinning medications

name: Elderberry and Ginger
uses: Reduces duration of colds and flu
preparationMethods: Syrup made from boiled elderberries and ginger, reduced and mixed with honey
cautions: Elderberry should not be consumed uncooked
rare cases of allergic reactions may occur
growingInformation: Elderberry: Prefers damp, fertile soil and full sun
Ginger: Ideally grown in rich and loose soil with ample water
harvestingInformation: Elderberry: Harvested late in the summer season
Ginger: Harvested 8-10 months after planting when the leaves have died down

children: Half a tablespoon of syrup daily

storageInstructions: Store in cool, dark place
interactionsWithMedications: None known

name: Sage and Lemon
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained soil and full sun exposure. It can be grown from seeds or cuttings.
harvestingInformation: Harvest leaves just before the plant blooms for highest concentration of active constituents.

dosageInformation.adult: 1 cup of sage-lemon tea three times daily
dosageInformation.children: 1/2 cup of sage-lemon tea three times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 cup of sage-lemon tea three times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place in a tightly sealed jar
interactions: May interact with sedative medications due to its thujone content
preparationMethods: Gargle solution made by steeping dried sage in hot water, then adding lemon juice and salt
cautions: Sage should be used with caution by nursing mothers as it can decrease milk supply

name: Lemongrass
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water with ginger
Can be used in cooking or salads
cautions: Avoid in pregnancy and breastfeeding
Can be allergenic for some people
sourceReferences: GARDNER, Z. & MCGUFFIN, M. 2013. American Herbal Products Association’s botanical safety handbook. CRC press.
JOYPP, R. & JOSEPH, M. 1998. Essential oil prospection of Cymbopogon citratus (DC.) Stapf from different places in India.
growingInformation: Requires full sun, good drainage, and prefers tropical climates
harvestingInformation: Harvest when stalks are mature and thick, typically in late summer
shelfLife: Dried lemongrass can be stored for up to 2 years
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light

interactions.medications: May interact with antihypertensive drugs and chemotherapy agents

name: Bay Leaf
preparationMethods: Steam inhalation with boiling water and eucalyptus
cautions: Can interfere with diabetes medication
Allergic reactions
growingInformation: Full sunlight, well-drained soil, grows in moderate climates
harvestingInformation: Early summer when leaves are most aromatic, allow to dry before storing

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 leaves in tea infusion or cooking, do not consume whole leaves
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 leaf in tea infusion or cooking, do not consume whole leaves

storageInstructions: Store in airtight container, in cool, dark place
interactionsWithMedications: May interfere with insulin and other diabetes medications

name: Usnea
uses: Used in a herbal wash for cuts, scrapes, and minor wounds to prevent infections and support tissue repair.
Sometimes used orally for bronchitis and other respiratory tract infections.
preparationMethods: Simmered in water with yarrow, then strained and cooled for use.
Taken orally as a capsule or tincture.
cautions: Not recommended for pregnant or breast-feeding women.
May cause stomach upset.
growingInfo: A lichen that grows on the bark of trees in cool, damp habitats.
harvestingInfo: Harvested in late summer and fall.

dosageInfo.adult: 200-400 mg capsules 2-3 times daily or 1-2 ml of tincture three times daily
dosageInfo.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years old
dosageInfo.elderly: Use with caution, start with lower dose

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place.
medicationInteractions: May interfere with antibiotics and other medications processed by the liver.

name: Myrrh
preparationMethods: Dried powder mixed with goldenseal powder and sea salt for a gum health powder
For skin wounds, apply the diluted oil directly to the wound
cautions: Should not be ingested in large quantities; can be toxic
Pregnant women should avoid using myrrh
May lower blood sugar levels, so caution is required for people with diabetes
growingInformation: Myrrh is a tree that grows in desert conditions. It requires full sun and dry, well-draining soil.
harvestingInformation: The resin is harvested by making cuts in the bark of the tree and allowing the resin to flow out and harden before it is collected.

dosageInformation.adult: For oral hygiene, use a mouthwash containing 0.1-0.2% myrrh tincture. For other uses, consult a qualified herbalist.
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children without medical supervision
dosageInformation.elderly: For oral hygiene, use a mouthwash containing 0.1-0.2% myrrh tincture. For other uses, consult a qualified herbalist.

shelfLife: Up to 2 years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place in an airtight container, away from light
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diabetes medications, anticoagulants, and sedatives

name: Berberine-containing herbs
properties: Effective against various bacteria including H. pylori, E. coli, and MRSA by disrupting bacterial cell walls and inhibiting enzyme function
uses: May also be used for respiratory infections
preparationMethods: Typically ground into a powder and taken in capsule form
Can be steeped in alcohol to create a tincture
cautions: Can cause digestive upset in some individuals and may interact with medications
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: WebMD. (2022). Berberine: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning. WebMD. https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-1126/berberine
Healthline. (2022). The many benefits of berberine. Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/berberine-powerful-supplement
growingInformation: Thrives in shaded, damp environments. Prefers well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Roots and stem bark are harvested in late fall or early spring.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years of age

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place with the container sealed tightly.
interactionsWithMedications: Can decrease the effectiveness of some medications, including cyclosporine and ranitidine. Always consult a healthcare provider before starting any new supplement regimen.

name: Tea tree oil
preparationMethods: Should always be diluted before applying to the skin to avoid irritation
cautions: Should not be ingested and should be used with caution on sensitive skin
Avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes
Do not use on children under 6 years old
extractionMethod: Steam distillation from leaves and branches
dilutionRatios: Generally, a 2% dilution (10 drops of essential oil in 30 mL of carrier oil) is safe for topical application in adults
carrierOilRecommendations: Jojoba oil, almond oil, olive oil, coconut oil
safetyPrecautions: Perform a patch test before using on larger areas of skin
Avoid using with pregnant or breastfeeding women
Do not use on deep wounds or serious burns
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from heat and light

name: Garlic and Honey Antimicrobial Tonic
preparationMethods: Garlic cloves are peeled, crushed, and infused in honey for 1-2 weeks
cautions: People with allergies to garlic or honey should avoid this remedy
May interact with medications, particularly blood thinners
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Garlic grows well in full sun with well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Garlic is typically harvested in the late summer
dosageInformation: Adults: 1 tablespoon daily
Children: Consult a healthcare practitioner
Elderly: Consult a healthcare practitioner
shelfLife: Store mixture for up to 1 month
storageInstructions: Store in airtight jar in cool, dark location
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners

name: Echinacea and Goldenseal Immune Tincture
uses: fighting infections such as colds and flu
preparationMethods: Roots are soaked in alcohol for 4-6 weeks
cautions: Not recommended for prolonged use
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Johnson, R. L., & Foster, S. (2006). Desk reference to nature's medicine. National Geographic Books.
growingInformation: Both plants are perennials that prefer full sun and well-drained soil. They usually bloom in the summer.
harvestingInformation: Roots are harvested in the fall after the plants have observed a few growing seasons.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with immunosuppressive drugs

name: Elderberry and Ginger Immune Syrup
uses: Prevention and treatment at the first sign of illness
preparationMethods: Elderberries and ginger are simmered, then mixed with honey after straining.
cautions: Raw honey should not be given to children under 1 year of age.
May cause allergic reactions in some individuals
growingInfo: Elderberries are shrubs that prefer full to partial sun and well-drained soil. Ginger can be grown indoors and outdoors, given warm conditions and moist, well-draining soil.
harvestingInfo: Elderberries are harvested in late summer to fall. Ginger can be harvested in fall or after the first year of growth.

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 tablespoons daily or every 2-3 hours when feeling unwell
dosageInformation.children: 1-2 teaspoons daily, not advised in children under 1 year of age due to honey

shelfLife: Refrigerated Elderberry syrup can last up to 2-3 months. Ginger root can store for up to 2-3 weeks in a cool, dark place.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place or refrigerate. Avoid exposing to high heat and sunlight.
medicationInteractions: May interact with medications that suppress immune system, certain pain medications and blood thinners

name: Horehound
preparationMethods: Cough drops made by simmering dried horehound with licorice root, water, and honey
cautions: May cause hypoglycemia in large doses
Not recommended for pregnant women
May interfere with blood sugar control during and after surgical procedures
sourceReferences: WebMD. (2021). Horehound: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning. https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-600/horehound
National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health. (2021). Horehound. https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/horehound
GrowingInformation: Can be grown in diverse conditions but prefers a sunny position in well-drained soil, relatively hardy and resistant to drought
HarvestingInformation: Leaves and flowering tops are harvested in late summer

DosageInformation.Adults: 1-4 grams of the dried herb in tea form up to three times daily, 1-2 mL of tincture three times daily

StorageInstructions: Keep in a dark, dry, and cool place in an airtight container
MedicationInteractions: May interact with diabetes medication and antiarrhythmic drugs

name: Barberry Root
uses: Supports the body’s defenses against infections
preparationMethods: Tincture made by macerating dried root in alcohol, often combined with Oregon grape root
Can also made into a tea or decoction
cautions: Avoid during pregnancy
Not recommended for long term use without proper consultation from healthcare practitioner
growingInformation: Grows in sunny to lightly shaded areas, prefers well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Root should be harvested in fall or early spring

dosageInformation.adult: 500mg to 1,000mg of root extract 3 times per day
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years old
dosageInformation.elderly: 500mg of root extract 1-2 times per day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Avoid sunlight and moisture.

interactions.medications: May interact with blood thinners, blood pressure medications, and antibiotics

name: Elecampane
preparationMethods: Cough elixir made with dried elecampane root, dried licorice root, water, and raw honey
cautions: Avoid usage if you are allergic to ragweed and related plants
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Herbs at a Glance - Elecampane, National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, NIH
Elecampane - Inula helenium, Monograph, Herbal Medicine, BMJ Journals
growingInformation: Elecampane is usually grown in moist, rich and well-drained soil under full to partial sun exposure
harvestingInformation: Roots and rhizomes are generally harvested in late summer or autumn of the second year of growth

dosageInformation.adult: Recommended dosage is usually 1-2 grams of dry root, three times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May affect blood clotting, avoid usage with anticoagulants
Can increase the effects of sedatives

name: Licorice
uses: Supports adrenal function and reduces stress
Aids in digestive problems like heartburn
cautions: Pregnant women should avoid licorice root
People suffering from kidney, liver disease, hypertension or hypokalemia should consult with medical professional before using licorice
growingInfo: Licorice prefers a deep well-drained loam with full sun or partial shade
harvestingInfo: Licorice roots are harvested in autumn from plants that are three or four years old

dosageInfo.adult: 250-500mg of standardized root extract three times daily
dosageInfo.elderly: Dose may need to be reduced depending on other health conditions

storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Licorice can interact with certain medications such as diuretics, insulin, corticosteroids, and cardiac glycosides

name: Bayberry
preparationMethods: Throat gargle made with dried bayberry root, dried sage, hot water, and sea salt
Topical application in the form of a cream or salve
cautions: Avoid during pregnancy or breastfeeding
Not for long term use
sourceReferences: Bayberry: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning. (n.d.). WebMD. https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-218/bayberry
growingInformation: Bayberries prefer full sun to partial shade, well-drained soil, and regular water. They are slow-growing and can be grown from seeds or cuttings.
harvestingInformation: Roots and barks are harvested in the fall and should be dried for medicinal use.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry, and dark place in airtight containers
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with medications metabolized by liver, consult with healthcare provider before use

name: Butterbur
uses: Effective for managing respiratory allergies such as asthma and hay fever
Can also help in reducing migraines
preparationMethods: Can also be made into tea
growingInformation: Prefers a rich, well-drained loamy soil in a sunny position. It's also capable of growing in semi-shade
harvestingInformation: Leaves should be harvested in late spring, roots in the fall
dosageInformation: Recommended dosage for adults is 75mg twice daily, not suitable for children and the elderly
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark place, out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with antihistamines and warfarin
cautions: Raw plant contains harmful substances; only use processed forms free of pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs)

name: Eyebright
uses: and eye drops for eye health
topically as a poultice for skin inflammations
as a rinse for allergies and sinusitis
cautions: None specified
Avoid during pregnancy
sourceReferences: The Modern Herbal Dispensatory: A Medicine-Making Guide

harvestingInformation.whenToHarvest: Late summer when the plant is flowering
harvestingInformation.howToHarvest: Cut off the entire plant close to the ground

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 grams of dried herb as tea, 3 times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: May increase effects of other drugs taken at the same time

name: Goldenrod
uses: Used to treat infections of the urinary tract
preparationMethods: Dried powder mixed with sage powder to fill capsules
Can be brewed as a tea
cautions: None mentioned
People with allergies to ragweed, marigolds, or daisies should avoid goldenrod
sourceReferences: WebMD - Goldenrod Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning
growingInformation: Goldenrod is a perennial that prefers full sun and dry to medium moisture soil.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in late summer and early fall when the plants are in full bloom.
activeConstituents: Flavonoids, saponins, phenolic acids, and tannins

dosageInformation.adult: 15-30 drops of a liquid extract, three times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: 15 drops of a liquid extract, three times daily

shelfLife: 2-3 years when stored properly in a cool, dry place
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light, heat, and moisture
interactionsWithMedications: may increase the risk of bleeding when taken with drugs that increase the risk of bleeding e.g., aspirin, anticoagulants, antiplatelet drugs

name: Green Tea
preparationMethods: Toner made by steeping 1 tablespoon Green Tea leaves in 1 cup hot water for 10 minutes, then mixed with Aloe Vera gel
cautions: Avoid excessive consumption as it may lead to stomach upset
Not recommended for patients with heart conditions
growingInformation: Thrives best in tropical and subtropical climates
harvestingInformation: Often picked by hand; only the top 1 to 2 inches of the mature plant are picked

dosageInformation.elderly: 1-2 cups per day depending on tolerance

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, packaged in a sealed, dark container away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact negatively with beta blockers, blood thinners, and anti-anxiety medications

name: Bromelain
uses: Combined with Quercetin for enhanced anti-allergy effects
Reduces nasal congestion and improves respiratory functions
preparationMethods: Can be taken in capsule, tablet or powder form
cautions: Should not be taken by people with pineapple allergies
May interact with certain medications such as anticoagulants and antibiotics
GrowingInformation: Bromelain is derived from the pineapple plant, which prefers a tropical climate and well-drained soil
HarvestingInformation: The stems or the mature fruits of the pineapple plant are harvested for bromelain extraction

DosageInformation.Children: Consult a healthcare professional for appropriate dosage

StorageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
InteractionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants and certain antibiotics, consult your healthcare professional before use

name: Reishi
uses: Used in combination with Eleuthero to support stress reduction, particularly after exercise
Traditionally used for boosting the immune system
preparationMethods: Powder form to be filled in empty gel capsules
cautions: May interact with blood thinning medications or immune-suppressing drugs. Consult with a healthcare provider before use
growingInformation: Thrives in humid climates with temperatures ranging from 70 to 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Prefer hardwood logs or sawdust as a growing medium. Can be grown indoors in bags or outdoor on logs.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the spores are visible below the mushroom cap, usually around late summer or early fall.

dosageInformation.adult: 3-5 grams per day in capsule form
dosageInformation.elderly: 3 grams per day in capsule form

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of sunlight. Keep out of reach of children.

interactionsWithMedications.bloodThinners: Interaction. Consult a doctor before use
interactionsWithMedications.immuneSuppressingDrugs: Interaction. Consult a doctor before use

name: Nettle and Dandelion Tea
preparationMethods: Steep dandelion root and nettle leaves in hot water for 15 minutes, strain, and add lemon juice
cautions: Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult a healthcare provider before use
May cause allergic reactions in some individuals
sourceReferences: The Herbal Drugstore by Linda B. White and Steven Foster
Herbal Medicine: Biomolecular and Clinical Aspects by Iris F.F Benzie and Sissi Wachtel-Galor
growingInformation: Nettles prefer rich soil and moist, shaded areas. Dandelions prefer full to partial sun and grow in a wide range of soil types.
harvestingInformation: Harvest Nettles in spring or early summer, and before they flower. Dandelion roots are best harvested in autumn.
activeConstituents: Flavonoids, Vitamins (A, C, and K), and minerals (Nettle)
Inulin, Pectin, Potassium, and Phenolic acids (Dandelion)

dosageInformation.adults: Drink 1-3 cups daily. Steep 1 teaspoon of blend in hot water for 10-15 minutes before drinking
dosageInformation.elderly: As advised by a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Up to 1 year when stored properly
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark, and dry place in a tightly sealed container
interactionsWithMedications: May interfere with diuretic and diabetes medications. Consult a healthcare provider if you are on any medications

name: Elderberry and Echinacea Syrup
uses: Reduces the duration and severity of colds and flu
preparationMethods: Boil elderberries, echinacea root, and water, simmer for 30 minutes, strain, reduce liquid by half, remove from heat, and stir in honey
cautions: May cause allergic reactions in some individuals
Avoid usage during pregnancy and breastfeeding
sourceReferences: Elderberry and Echinacea Syrup Recipe: The Herbal Academy
Evidence Based Efficacy of Echinacea and Elderberry: Pubmed
growingInformation: Elderberry: Prefers wet, fertile soil and full sunlight
Echinacea: Prefers well-drained soil and full to partial sunlight
harvestingInformation: Elderberry: Harvest in late summer to early fall
Echinacea: Harvest roots in fall of 3rd year of growth
dosageInformation: Adults: 1 tablespoon 3 times daily
Children: Consult pediatrician
Elderly: 1 tablespoon 2 times daily
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with immunosuppressant medications

name: Chamomile and Lavender Tea
preparationMethods: Steep chamomile and lavender in hot water for 15 minutes
cautions: Should be avoided by individuals with allergies to the Asteraceae/Compositae family (Chamomile)
Excessive consumption can lead to sedation (Lavender)
growingInformation: Both chamomile and lavender prefer full sunlight and well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest when flowers are fully opened, typically in late summer
shelfLife: Dried flowers can last up to 1-2 years if properly stored
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry, dark place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: Potentially with sedatives, anticoagulants and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)

name: Devil’s Claw and Ginger Capsules
uses: Manages arthritis and other inflammatory joint conditions
preparationMethods: Mix Devil’s Claw and ginger root powders, fill empty vegetable capsules
cautions: Avoid if allergic to members of the sesame plant family, as devils claw is part of this family
Consult with doctor if pregnant, nursing, or if you have a medical condition before use
plantFamily: Pedaliaceae for Devil's Claw and Zingiberaceae for Ginger
growingInformation: Devil’s Claw is a desert plant native to southern Africa. Ginger is a tropical plant that grows in warm, humid conditions.
harvestingInformation: Devil’s Claw is harvested for its roots, which are peeled and dried. Ginger can be harvested year round but the roots are typically harvested after the plant stops producing leaves.
activeConstituents: Harpagosides in Devil's Claw and Gingerols in Ginger

dosageInformation.elderly: Dose adjustments may be required due to potential interaction with chronic disease medications

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants, antiplatelet drugs, hypotensive drugs, and anti-arrhythmia drugs

name: Turmeric and Ginger Golden Milk
preparationMethods: Heat almond milk, turmeric, ginger, and cinnamon gently, stirring continuously, remove from heat and stir in honey
cautions: Avoid if allergic to ginger or turmeric
Consult a healthcare provider before use if pregnant, nursing, or  have a medical condition.
growingInformation: Ginger and turmeric both thrive in warm, humid climates and can be grown in pots indoors.
harvestingInformation: Ginger and turmeric roots can be harvested 8-10 months after planting.

dosageInformation.elderly: 1 cup daily, unless advised otherwise by a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Golden milk should be consumed within 2 days of preparation
storageInstructions: Store in refrigerator and reheat as needed
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinners
May interact with diabetes medication

name: Cinnamon and Clove Tea
preparationMethods: Steep a cinnamon stick and whole cloves in hot water for 10-15 minutes, strain, and add honey to taste. Drink 1-2 cups daily.
cautions: Overconsumption can lead to mouth irritation and stomach upset. People with liver damage, diabetes or pregnant women should consult their healthcare provider before use.

growingInformation.Cinnamon: Tropical evergreen tree that prefers well-draining soil and full sun. Grows best in USDA zones 10-12.
growingInformation.Clove: Tropical evergreen tree that prefers well-draining soil and partial shade. Grows best in USDA zones 9-12.

harvestingInformation.Cinnamon: Bark is harvested during the rainy season when flexible and then dried into sticks.
harvestingInformation.Clove: Buds are harvested before they open and then sun-dried.

shelfLife: Brewed tea should be consumed within 24 hours if refrigerated. Dry cinnamon sticks and cloves can last up to 3 years if stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store dry cinnamon sticks and cloves in an airtight container in a cool, dry, and dark place.
interactionsWithMedications: May lower blood sugar levels, affecting diabetes medications
May slow blood clotting, affecting anticoagulant medications

name: Cinnamon and Clove
uses: May help regulate blood sugar levels
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water for 10-15 minutes, strain, add honey if desired
Can be ground and used in cooking and baking
cautions: None specified
Avoid excessive consumption as it can be harmful
People with liver damage, diabetes, or who are pregnant should consult a doctor before consuming

growingInformation.cinnamon: Tropical climate, well-draining soil, partial sun
growingInformation.clove: Tropical climate, well-draining loam soil, full sun

harvestingInformation.cinnamon: Harvest the inner bark after two years
harvestingInformation.clove: Harvest the flower buds just before they bloom

dosageInformation.adults: 0.5-2g daily for cinnamon; 2-4g daily for clove

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight
interactions: Can affect blood clotting: Avoid using with anticoagulant medications
May interfere with blood sugar medication

name: Holy Basil and Lemon Balm

cautions: Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult with a healthcare provider before using. Lemon balm may interact with sedative and thyroid medications.
harvestingInformation: Harvest just before flowering for the highest essential oil content.

dosageInformation.Adults: 2-4 grams of the dried herb per cup, 2-3 times daily

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with sedative and thyroid medications

name: Calendula and Plantain
uses: Promotes faster healing of minor cuts, scrapes, and burns

cautions: Avoid usage if allergic to marigolds or related plants.
Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult with a healthcare professional before usage.

growingInformation.Calendula: Full sun, fertile soil with good drainage. Sow seeds in spring.
growingInformation.Plantain: Full sun to part shade, adapts to many soil conditions. Sow seeds in late summer to early fall.

harvestingInformation.Calendula: Harvest flowers in morning after dew has evaporated.

storageInstructions: Store in cool, dry place away from sunlight

interactions.medications: May interact with medications affecting blood clotting

name: Passionflower and Skullcap
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water for 10-15 minutes
cautions: Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult a physician.
May interact with sedatives and other medications.

Pharmacological studies in an herbal drug combination of St. John's Wort (Hypericum perforatum) and passionflower (Passiflora incarnata): in vitro and in vivo evidence of synergy between Hypericum and Passiflora in antidepressant pharmacological models. Fitoterapia, 82(3), 474-480.
growingInformation: Prefers full sun to part shade
Prefers well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest flowers in the morning after dew has evaporated

Keep in airtight container

name: Aloe Vera and Peppermint
properties: Soothes and heals the digestive system

cautions: Avoid use during pregnancy
Excessive consumption may cause diarrhea
sourceReferences: Herbal Medicine: Biomolecular and Clinical Aspects. 2nd edition, Benzie IFF, Wachtel-Galor S, editors. CRC Press; 2011.
growingInformation: Tropical climate for Aloe Vera & Temperate for Peppermint
Well-drained soil

Peppermint: before flowering

Consult a doctor for children and elderly
shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored properly

Refrigerate mix after preparation
