name: Rosehips
preparationMethods: Can be used in teas, syrups, or as a supplement
cautions: Possible allergic reactions
May interfere with certain medications such as anticoagulants or blood pressure medications
growingInformation: This perennial plant prefers full sun and well-draining soil. It is drought resistant and can adapt to different conditions.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in autumn, after the first frost, when the rosehips are fully ripe and red. Use gloves as the bushes can be thorny.
shelfLife: Up to one year if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from heat and light.
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulant medications
Blood pressure medications

name: Chaga
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water with Reishi and honey
cautions: Should not be used by people with bleeding disorders or undergoing surgery
growingInformation: Grows predominantly on birch trees in cold climates
harvestingInformation: Harvest in late summer or early fall
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulant / Antiplatelet drugs

name: Devil’s Claw
preparationMethods: Combined with alcohol for a tincture
mixed with Willow Bark powder for capsules
cautions: May interact with heart and blood pressure medications.
growingInfo: Thrives in well-drained, sandy or gravelly soils, and loves bright sunlight.
harvestingInfo: The roots and tubers are harvested in the second year of growth, during spring or early summer.

dosageInformation.adult: Typically 600-1200 mg daily in tablet or capsule form
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with low dosage under physician's supervision

storageInstructions: Store in a dry, cool place, away from direct sunlight
interactionWithMedications: May interfere with blood thinners, heart medications, and stomach acid reducers

name: St. John's Wort
uses: Relief from nerve pain or sciatica
Used to treat mild to moderate depression
preparationMethods: Can also be consumed as tea or in capsule form
cautions: May interact with certain medications, including antidepressants
Avoid sun exposure as it can increase skin sensitivity
growingInformation: St. John's Wort is a perennial plant that thrives in sunny locations with well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: The herb should be harvested just as the flowers begin to open, typically in mid to late summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 300mg three times a day, with meals

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: Can interact with antidepressants, birth control pills, and other medications. Consult a healthcare professional.

name: Oregano Oil Capsules
preparationMethods: Blend dried oregano leaves into a powder, mix with olive oil, fill empty vegetable capsules
cautions: Limit use to up to 2 weeks
Avoid use during pregnancy and while breastfeeding
Potential allergic reactions in some individuals

dilutionRatios.Topical usage: 1-2 drops essential oil per tablespoon of carrier oil
dilutionRatios.Internal use: As recommended by a healthcare professional

safetyPrecautions: Always dilute before use
Avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from heat and light

name: Lemon Balm and Cat’s Claw Antiviral Tea
preparationMethods: Steep lemon balm leaves and cat’s claw bark in hot water for 10-15 minutes
cautions: Not advisable for pregnant women
People with low blood pressure should use with caution

growingInformation.lemonBalm: Grows in well-drained soil, full sunshine or part shade

harvestingInformation.lemonBalm: Harvest before flowers bloom for best flavor
harvestingInformation.catsClaw: Harvest the bark carefully to avoid killing the tree

shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored correctly
storageInstructions: dry, airtight container, away from light, heat, and humidity

name: Usnea and Calendula Wound Wash
uses: Promoting faster healing of minor cuts and abrasions
preparationMethods: Simmer usnea and calendula in water, strain, and cool for use as a wash
cautions: For external use only, on minor wounds. Discontinue use if irritation or rash appears.
growingInformation: Usnea: grows on trees in damp climates. Calendula: can be grown in a garden or pot, prefers full sun exposure
harvestingInformation: Usnea: only take small sections. Calendula: the flowers are harvested

adult: Use enough wash to cover the wound
Minimum 1 application a day, can be used more frequently if needed
children: Reduce quantity relative to size of wound, minimum 1 application a day
elderly: Use enough wash to cover the wound
Consider skin sensitivity when determining frequency of application

shelfLife: Do not use past expiry date if bought pre-made
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place. If homemade, refrigerate after use
interactionsWithMedications: No known significant interactions

name: Licorice Root Antiviral Tea
uses: Lessens the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome
preparationMethods: Steep 1-2 grams of dried licorice root in hot water for 10-15 minutes
cautions: People with hypertension, pregnant women, and those with kidney disease should avoid due to glycyrrhizin content
growingInformation: Licorice prefers full sun and well-drained soil. It can be propagated by seeds, cuttings, or root divisions in spring or autumn.
harvestingInformation: Licorice roots are typically harvested in the autumn of their third or fourth year of growth.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diuretics, corticosteroids, and medication for cardiovascular disease.

name: Holy Basil and Ginger Immunity Tea
preparationMethods: Steep holy basil and grated ginger in hot water, add honey if desired
cautions: Avoid use during pregnancy or consult your healthcare provider.
growingInformation: Holy Basil thrives in full to part sun, high heat and well-drained soil. Ginger prefers part shade and rich, loose soil.
harvestingInformation: Leaves of Holy Basil can be harvested throughout the growing season. Ginger rhizomes can be harvested 8 to 10 months after planting.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood-thinning medications, consult your healthcare provider before use.

name: Black Walnut
uses: Supports the elimination of intestinal parasites and cleanses the digestive system.
It can be utilized for its astringent properties for skin issues like eczema and acne.
preparationMethods: Used in capsule form, often combined with other herbs like Garlic.
For topical applications, a tincture or poultice is prepared.
cautions: May interact with certain medications and is not recommended for pregnant women.
People with nut allergies should avoid this herb.
sourceReferences: WebMD. (n.d.). Black Walnut: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning.
University of Michigan Health. (2017). Black Walnut.
growingInformation: Prefers well-drained soil and a sunny location. It can reach heights of 100 feet.
harvestingInformation: The fruit hulls are harvested in the fall when they are green and still soft.

dosageInformation.adult: 500-1000mg as decoction or capsule form daily
dosageInformation.children: use under supervision of healthcare provider
dosageInformation.elderly: 500-1000mg as decoction or capsule form daily

shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored appropriately.
storageInstructions: Keep in an airtight container in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight.
interactions: May interact with thyroid medications, and substances that slow blood clotting.

name: Lavender (Steam)
preparationMethods: Dilution in a carrier oil for topical application
cautions: Inhalation is generally safe; avoid contact with eyes
Do not ingest
Always dilute before topical application
May not be suitable for people with sensitive skin
dilution_ratios: 1-2 drops of lavender oil to 1 tablespoon of carrier oil
safety_precautions: Avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding without medical consultation. Keep out of reach of children.
storage_instructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from direct sunlight, with the top firmly closed.

sourceReferences.author: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health

name: Aloe Vera
properties: Nourishes the scalp and promotes hair regrowth.
Has anti-inflammatory and healing properties, useful in treating skin problems.
uses: Used in a hair regrowth mask with fenugreek.
Used to treat minor burns, sunburns and small abrasions.
preparationMethods: Blended with soaked fenugreek seeds to form a paste.
Applied as is on burns or skin problems.
cautions: Test for skin sensitivity before applying to the scalp.
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult a healthcare professional before use.
Oral use may lower blood glucose levels and could interfere with diabetes medications.

dosageInformation.adult: Topical: As needed. Oral: Consult with a healthcare professional.
dosageInformation.children: Topical: As needed under adult supervision. Oral: Not recommended.
dosageInformation.elderly: Topical: As needed. Oral: Consult with a healthcare professional.

shelfLife: Aloe vera gel - Up to 2 weeks refrigerated, Aloe vera leaf - Up to a week at room temperature
storageInstructions: Store aloe vera gel in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Keep aloe vera leaf at room temperature away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Interferes with diabetes medications due to its hypoglycemic effect

name: Cordyceps Mushroom
uses: May help manage type 2 diabetes symptoms
cautions: May interact with immunosuppressant drugs
Safety in pregnant or breastfeeding women has not been established
sourceReferences: Health effects of Cordyceps militaris: A review. (2020). Journal of Functional Foods
Therapeutic applications of Cordyceps. (2020). Journal of Mycology
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight
interactions: May interact with immunosuppressant drugs
May lower blood sugar

name: Shiitake
preparationMethods: Sauté with other mushrooms, Astragalus root, and Chaga powder in olive oil
Add to vegetable broth with seasonings and simmer for 30 minutes
cautions: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals
growingInformation: Prefers humid climates and grows on decaying hardwood trees or on specially prepared substrates.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when caps have opened fully, typically in spring and fall.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light
interactionsWithMedications: May potentiate antidiabetic and anticoagulant medications

name: Maitake
preparationMethods: Cook with Shiitake, Reishi, Astragalus root, and Chaga powder in vegetable broth
cautions: None specified
growingInformation: Maitake mushrooms are woodland fungi that usually grow at the base of Oak trees. They prefer damp, humid conditions and rich, fertile soil.
harvestingInformation: Maitake mushrooms are typically harvested in the fall. They should be picked when young and tender for best taste and nutritional properties.

dosageInformation.children: Dosage should be adjusted based on weight under the guidance of a healthcare provider
dosageInformation.elderly: Dose may need to be reduced due to potential interaction with other medicinal drugs

shelfLife: Fresh Maitake mushrooms should be used within 10 days of harvest. Capsules and powders can last up to 2 years when stored correctly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place. Fresh mushrooms should be kept in the refrigerator.
interactions: May lower blood sugar levels so caution should be exercised when taking with diabetes medications.
May increase the potency of anticoagulant drugs.
evidenceLevel: Moderate. Some clinical trials have shown the immune-enhancing properties of Maitake, but more research is needed.
sourceReferences: Deng G., Lin H., Seidman A., et al. A phase I/II trial of a polysaccharide extract from Grifola frondosa (Maitake mushroom) in breast cancer patients: immunological effects. J Cancer Res Clin Oncol. 2009;135(9):1215–1221.
Kodama N., Komuta K., Nanba H. Can maitake MD-fraction aid cancer patients? Altern Med Rev. 2002;7(3):236–239.

name: Goji Berries
uses: Included in energy bars for sustained fuel and vitality
Consume dried goji berries directly, added to tea, soups and salads
May improve mood and digestive health
preparationMethods: Combined with Maca, oats, and almonds to make nutritious bars
Can be steeped in hot water to make a tea
May be consumed raw or added to cooking
cautions: Can interact with certain medications, including blood thinners and diabetes drugs
interactionsWithMedications: Blood thinners, diabetes medications, blood pressure medications
sourceReferences: Cheng J, Zhou ZW, Sheng HP, He LJ, Fan XW, He ZX, Sun T, Zhang X, Zhao RJ, Gu L, Cao C, Zhou SF. An evidence-based update on the pharmacological activities and possible molecular targets of Lycium barbarum polysaccharides. Drug Des Devel Ther. 2015;9:33–78. doi:10.2147/DDDT.S72892
growingInformation: Goji berries thrive in well-drained, slightly alkaline soil and full sun exposure. They are drought-tolerant once established and tolerant of frost once mature.
harvestingInformation: Goji berries ripen in late summer and can be harvested by shaking the plant. The berries should be allowed to dry and wrinkle before consumption.
activeConstituents: Polysaccharides, carotenoids, phenolics, vitamins (B1, B2, B6, C and E), minerals

dosageInformation.children: Consult with a professional before giving to children

shelfLife: Dried goji berries can be stored for up to 1 year
storageInstructions: Store dried goji berries in a cool, dark location in a sealed container

name: Elderberries
uses: used to treat flu and cold symptoms
preparationMethods: can be made into syrups, wine, and teas
cautions: Raw elderberries should not be consumed as they may cause nausea and vomiting
do not exceed the recommended dosage
growingInformation: Elder trees prefer full sun or partial shade
They grow well in well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Berries and flowers are harvested in late summer and early fall

dosageInformation.adults: 10-30 ml of elderberry juice extract daily

shelfLife: Up to 1 year when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place
Keep away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Elderberries may interact with diuretics and laxatives
May decrease the effects of medications that suppress the immune system

name: Lemon Peel
uses: Used in tea to enhance vitality
preparationMethods: Steep 1 tablespoon of dried peel with Schisandra in hot water for 15 minutes.
cautions: Ensure it is free from pesticides and thoroughly washed.
growingInformation: Lemons are best grown in well-draining, sandy loam soil in a sunny location, they prefer a soil pH between 6 and 7.
harvestingInformation: Lemon fruits are harvested when they are fully colored and have a bit of give when gently squeezed.

dosageInformation.adult: 1 tablespoon steeped in tea 2-3 times daily
dosageInformation.children: 1-2 teaspoons steeped in tea 1-2 times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 teaspoon steeped in tea 1-2 times daily

shelfLife: Dried lemon peel can last 2-3 years if stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place in an airtight container.

name: Acerola Cherry
cautions: Excessive consumption can cause gastrointestinal discomfort
Might cause allergies to some
Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult a doctor
growingInformation: It grows in warm climates, preferably in well-draining soil. Full sun exposure and adequate watering are required.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the fruit is bright red and fully ripe. Try to consume immediately as it starts to spoil shortly after.
shelfLife: Up to one year if kept in cool and dark place
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place. If fresh, refrigerate and consume within 3 days.
