Can affect the absorption of certain chemotherapeutic drugs

name: Alfalfa
properties: Rich in minerals supporting bone formation.
uses: Brewed in a tea to enhance mineral density of bones.
Can be used as a nutritional supplement.
preparationMethods: Steep 1 tablespoon dried Alfalfa in 2 cups hot water for 15 minutes.
cautions: May interact with blood thinners and hormone therapies.
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactions: May interfere with the effects of warfarin and other anticoagulants
May affect hormone levels and interfere with hormone therapy

growingInformation.cultivation: Sow seeds in spring or fall, thin to 18 inches apart.
growingInformation.harvesting: Harvest young leaves during the flowering stage for highest nutrient content.

name: Chickweed
properties: Known for its cooling and soothing properties, Chickweed supports skin health and offers anti-inflammatory benefits.
uses: Infused in vinegar for a nutrient-rich tonic
Used in creams to support wound healing
preparationMethods: Commonly infused in apple cider vinegar
cautions: Pregnant women should avoid using Chickweed due to limited research on its effects.
sourceReferences: Healthline, 'Chickweed: Benefits, Side Effects, and Dosage'
growingInformation: Chickweed grows in a variety of environments, from gardens to meadows, and prefers cool, moist conditions.
harvestingInformation: Harvest chickweed in the spring before it goes to seed for the best nutritional content.
shelfLife: Fresh chickweed can be stored in the refrigerator for up to a week. Dried chickweed should be stored in a sealed container in a cool, dark place and used within a year.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from moisture.
interactionsWithMedications: Diuretics: Chickweed may increase the effect of diuretic drugs.

name: Sunflower Seeds
preparationMethods: Can be added to various dishes
cautions: High calorie count; consume in moderation
May contain high sodium; monitor if on a low-sodium diet
growingInformation: Sunflowers prefer full sun, with at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. They prefer well-draining soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.5.
harvestingInformation: Sunflower seeds are ready to harvest once the back of the flower head is brown and the outer shell of the seeds are hard.
activeConstituents: Magnesium, Potassium, Selenium, Zinc, Vitamin B1
shelfLife: Kept in an airtight container in a cool, dry place, the seeds can last up to 6 months.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dry place. Refrigerate for longer shelf life.
interactionsWithMedications: May affect blood sugar levels so caution is advised when using antidiabetic medications.

name: Pumpkin Seeds
uses: Can help manage blood sugar levels
preparationMethods: incorporated into herbal powders and trail mixes
cautions: Generally considered safe but may cause digestive upset in some individuals if consumed in large quantities
growingInformation: Pumpkin seeds come from the pumpkin plant, which is a warm-weather crop that is typically planted in late spring to early summer.
harvestingInformation: Pumpkin seeds can be harvested in autumn, when the pumpkin is ripe. They are removed from the pumpkin, rinsed and dried before use.
shelfLife: Pumpkin seeds can be stored for up to 6 months in a cool, dark and dry place.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dark and dry place. Can also be stored in the fridge to extend shelf life.
interactionsWithMedications: Pumpkin seeds may lower blood sugar levels and may interact with diabetes medications.

name: Mint
cautions: Avoid if you have an allergy to menthol
Interaction with medications, especially those dealing with acid reflux
growingInformation: Prefers a wet environment with partial shade, but can tolerate a variety of light conditions. Ideal for planting in spring.
harvestingInformation: Harvest just before flowering for maximum flavor. Can be harvested multiple times in a growing season.

dosageInformation.adult: 2-3 cups of tea per day or apply directly to skin as needed
dosageInformation.children: 1-2 cups of tea per day or apply directly to skin as needed
dosageInformation.elderly: 1-2 cups of tea per day or apply directly to skin as needed

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place. Dried leaves can be stored in an airtight container.
interactionsWithMeds: Can cause heartburn or exacerbate acid reflux when taken in conjunction with related medications

name: Rose
preparationMethods: Mix Rose water with Aloe Vera gel and Rosehip Seed Oil
cautions: May cause irritation in sensitive skin
sourceReferences: Thring, T. S. A., Hili, P., & Naughton, D. P. (2011). Antioxidant and potential anti-inflammatory activity of extracts and formulations of white tea, rose, and witch hazel on primary human dermal fibroblast cells.
growingInformation: Roses prefer well-drained soil rich in organic matter, with a pH between 6.5 and 7.0. They need at least six hours of sun each day. Deadhead spent blooms to encourage repeat flowering.
harvestingInformation: Roses are harvested in the cool morning hours when their oil content is at its highest. They should be used immediately after being cut.
activeConstituents: Rose oil, flavonoids, anthocyanins, carotenoids, and vitamins C and E.

dosageInformation.adult: For topical use only. Use as recommended by the product manufacturer or a qualified herbalist
dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 6 years old
dosageInformation.elderly: Use with caution and under professional supervision

shelfLife: Rosewater can last up to six months if refrigerated.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place. Refrigerate after opening.
interactionsWithMedications: No known interactions with conventional medications. However, a healthcare professional should be consulted before starting any herbal regimen.

name: Sandalwood
uses: Can be used in skincare for its moisturizing properties
preparationMethods: Applied topically when diluted with a carrier oil
cautions: May cause skin irritation in some individuals when applied topically
Avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding without medical guidance
Should not be ingested
dilutionRatios: 1-2 drops of sandalwood essential oil to 1 tablespoon of carrier oil
carrierOilRecommendations: Jojoba oil, coconut oil, or almond oil
safetyPrecautions: Always do a patch test before applying to larger areas of skin
Avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes
Stop usage immediately if irritation occurs
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place out of direct sunlight

name: Psyllium Husk
properties: Expands in the stomach, promoting a feeling of fullness.
uses: Used to reduce the likelihood of overeating by promoting a feeling of fullness.
Used as a dietary fiber to relieve symptoms of both constipation and mild diarrhea.
growing_information: Grown in cooler climates of the world. Psyllium plant reaches maturity in approximately two months, when its flowers develop into seeds.
harvesting_information: Harvesting takes place in the cooler part of the year, which ranges from early autumn to early winter. The upper portion of the plant is cut and dried in the sun, then threshed for the seeds.

dosage_information.adult: Typically used at doses of 5–10 g with meals, at least 30 minutes before eating.
dosage_information.children: Half the adult dosage, consult with a healthcare provider.
dosage_information.elderly: Begin with lowest recommended dosage. Increase as tolerated and as necessary.

storage_instructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Keep out of reach of children.
interactions_with_medications: Psyllium can delay or decrease the absorption of certain medications. Consult with healthcare provider before using.
preparationMethods: Mix 1 teaspoon of Psyllium Husk in 1 cup of water, stir well and drink immediately, followed by an additional glass of water.
cautions: None mentioned, but it's generally advised to consume with plenty of water to avoid gastrointestinal blockage.

name: Anise Seed
uses: used in traditional medicine for cough and asthma
preparationMethods: Steep Anise seeds in hot water for 15 minutes
Can be ground and added to food or drink
cautions: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women without the advice of a healthcare professional
sourceReferences: Agah, S., Taleb, A.M., Moeini, R., Farzaei, M.H., and Zargar A. (2018) The Role of Anise (Pimpinella anisum) in Managing and Treating Disease Conditions. In Molecular and Cellular Biochemistry. 449, 1–2, pp.107–118.
growingInfo: Anise prefers well-drained, light, sandy soil in full sun. Sow seeds directly in late spring, as Anise does not transplant well.
harvestingInfo: Seeds should be harvested as soon as they ripen and turn gray-brown, typically in late summer.
dosageInfo: Infusion: Steep 1-2 tsp of seeds in a cup of boiling water for 10-15 mins; drink thrice daily. Not recommended for children under 5.
shelfLife: Can be stored for up to 3 years in a cool, dark, dry place
storageInstructions: Store in airtight containers out of direct sunlight, in a cool and dry place
medicationInteractions: May interact with anticoagulant medications; consult with healthcare professional before use if on such medications

name: Peppermint Oil
properties: Relaxes smooth muscles of the digestive tract
uses: Alleviates cramping and spasms, especially related to IBS
Can also be used topically to help alleviate tension headaches
preparationMethods: Can be diluted and applied topically
cautions: None specified
It's highly concentrated, so should always be diluted when applied to the skin
Should be avoided by pregnant women and children under 6
dilutionRatios: 1-2% peppermint oil to carrier oil for topical application. Always do a patch test first
carrierOilRecommendations: Jojoba oil, Grapeseed oil, or Sweet almond oil
safetyPrecautions: Avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes. Not for internal use unless recommended by a healthcare practitioner
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place in a sealed container

name: Gentian Root
uses: Taken before meals to aid digestion
Used as a traditional medicinal remedy for digestive disorders
preparationMethods: Powder form, mixed with Yellow Dock Root powder for capsules
cautions: Should not be used by individuals with ulcers or high stomach acid
growingInformation: Gentian plants prefer cool climates and partial to full shade. They require well-drained, moist, acidic to neutral soil.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in autumn from plants that are 3 to 4 years old.

dosageInformation.children: Consult a healthcare professional for appropriate dosage
dosageInformation.elderly: Consult a healthcare professional for appropriate dosage

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight and moisture
interactions: May interact with antacid medications, reducing their effectiveness

name: Cardamom
preparationMethods: Crushed pods steeped with Ginger and Cinnamon
cautions: None specified
Overconsumption could lead to an upset stomach
sourceReferences: May B, Köhler S, Schneider B. Efficacy and tolerability of a fixed combination of peppermint oil and caraway oil in patients suffering from functional dyspepsia. Aliment Pharmacol Ther. 2000;14(12):1671-1677.
Azam F, Amer AM, Abulifa AR, Elzwawi MM. Spices as Alternative and Complementary Medicines: A Review. 2021;25(5):1457-1474.
growingInformation: Needs warm tropical climate, well-drained soil, and partial shade. Seeds are planted during the rainy season.
harvestingInformation: Harvest pods as they ripen, around 8 to 9 months after planting.
activeConstituents: Terpenes, flavonoids, phenolic acids, and tannins
shelfLife: Up to 3 years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants and antiplatelets due to its blood-thinning properties

name: Caraway
uses: Used in fermentations and culinary dishes to support digestive health.
Also used as a diuretic, to improve cardiovascular health, and to reduce menstrual cramps.
preparationMethods: Seeds are used in cooking, baking, and to flavor ferments.
cautions: None specified, but moderation is advised.
growingInformation: Caraway plants prefer full sun to partial shade and well-drained soil. They can be grown in the window sill or inside container, or in an outdoor garden.
harvestingInformation: Caraway seeds mature in the second year of growth. Harvest the seeds when they turn brown and store them in a cool, dry place.
shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light. Sealed containers are recommended.
interactionsWithMedications: May enhance the effects of anticoagulant medication. Consult your healthcare provider before use.

name: Coriander
uses: Helpful for digestive ease and comfort
May aid in lowering blood sugar levels
preparationMethods: Seeds steeped in hot water, often combined with Caraway
Coriander leaves used fresh in cooking
cautions: Generally safe, but use in moderation
Rare allergic reactions have been reported
growingInformation: Coriander is an annual herb that prefers full sun or partial shade and a well-drained soil. It takes about 6-7 weeks to grow.
harvestingInformation: Seeds should be harvested when they are brown and fall easily from the plant. Leaves can be harvested once the plant is established.

dosageInformation.adult: Up to one teaspoon of seeds daily

shelfLife: Seeds can last up to three years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with medications used for diabetes by lowering blood sugar levels too much

name: Plantain Leaf
growingInfo: Plantain leaf grows best in cool, moist climates in full sun to partial shade. The plant grows low to the ground and can preeminently cover an area without crowding out other plant species.
harvestingInfo: Leaves can be harvested anytime throughout its growing season, especially during spring and early summer when leaves are tender and have a better flavor. Always remember to harvest from areas that are free from pesticide or other harmful substances.
activeConstituents: Plantain leaf contains flavonoids, polysaccharides, lipids, caffeine acid, and alcohols expressing antibacterial and antiviral activity, among other constituents.

dosageInfo.adult: 1-2 teaspoons of dried leaves soaked in hot water for 10 minutes, up to 3 times a day.
dosageInfo.children: Same as adults, in proportion to body weight.
dosageInfo.elderly: As with adults, adjust in conjunction with any medications being used.

shelfLife: Kept in an airtight container in a cool, dark place, dried plantain leaves can last for up to a year.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container in a cool, dry, and dark location.
uses: Used to soothe irritated or inflamed internal tissues, such as those in the mouth and throat, and inflamed hemorrhoids.
Used in conjunction with Marshmallow Root for soothing the digestive tract.
preparationMethods: Simmer in water with Marshmallow Root for 20 minutes
cautions: None mentioned
interactionsWithMedication: May have an interactive effect with lithium, leading to increased lithium concentration and potential toxicity. Always consult a healthcare provider before combining herbs with prescription medications.
conditionsTreated: Inflammation of the mouth and throat
sourceReferences: Vitaliy Kamnev, Lidiya Kashpur, Natalya Sumtsova. (2018). Plantain: vitamins and health benefits. Advances in Food Science & Nutrition. Volume 3, Issue 2.

name: Anise
uses: Effective for relieving nausea and calming the digestive system.
Can help with insomnia and anxiety when consumed as a tea.
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water with Ginger and Peppermint for 15 minutes, then strain and serve warm.
Can also be used to flavor food and beverages.
cautions: None mentioned.
May cause allergic reactions in some people.
growingInformation: Anise prefers full sun and well-drained soil. It is a self-seeding annual plant that blooms in the second year.
harvestingInformation: Seeds can be harvested once they become brown and easy to separate from the umbels.
dosageInformation: One to two cups of anise tea per day for adults. Consult a healthcare practitioner for children and elderly dosages.
shelfLife: Dried anise seeds can be stored for up to two years.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light.
interactionsWithMedications: Can amplify effects of hormonal medicines due to estrogen-like properties. Consult a healthcare practitioner to avoid potential interactions.

name: Hops
uses: Used for insomnia or difficulty in relaxing
Used in combination with other herbs to promote sleep and relaxation
preparationMethods: Often included in sleep-promoting tea blends or taken as a tincture
cautions: Can cause drowsiness; use caution when combining with other sedatives
growingInformation: Thrives in well-drained, sandy soil in sunny areas. Hops is best grown in regions with long daylight hours during the summer.
harvestingInformation: Hops flowers are usually harvested in late summer or early fall. The flowers are fully mature when they are fragrant and spring back when squeezed.
activeConstituents: primarily lupulin, humulene, and other essential oils

dosageInformation.adults: 2-3 grams dried herb in tea, up to 3 times daily
dosageInformation.children: Use under the guidance of a healthcare professional
dosageInformation.elderly: Lower dosage may be appropriate; use under the guidance of a healthcare professional

shelfLife: Up to one year stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place
interactions: May increase the sedative effect of sleep medications and alcohol. Use caution when combining with other sedatives.

name: Psyllium
uses: Used in a daily gut cleanse drink to promote regularity and support gut health
preparationMethods: Mixed with Aloe Vera gel and warm water to create a drink
cautions: May cause bloating or gas in some individuals; adequate water intake is necessary
growingInformation: Prefers sandy or loamy soils and a sunny position. Not frost tolerant.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the seeds when they turn brown, typically late summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 5-10g, up to three times a day
dosageInformation.children: Should only be given under medical supervision
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with lower dose (5g/day) and adjust as necessary

shelfLife: Up to 2 years if properly stored
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May decrease the absorption of certain medications; separate intake by at least two hours

name: Gentian
properties: Stimulates the production of digestive enzymes.
uses: Can help to treat anorexia, indigestion, and stomach aches
preparationMethods: Mixed with yellow dock powder and filled into empty gel capsules.
cautions: None specified.
Should be avoided by those with a known allergy to gentian or its constituents.
Pregnant and nursing women should consult a healthcare professional before use.
growingInformation: Prefer well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade. Thrives in cooler temperatures.
harvestingInformation: Harvest roots and stems in autumn, after 3 to 5 years of growth.
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dark, dry place out of direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants
May interact with diabetic medication

name: Artichoke
preparationMethods: Simmer with burdock root in water for 30 minutes
Artichoke extract can be consumed in capsule form
cautions: May interact with diuretics and bile duct obstruction medications
May cause allergic reaction in people who are allergic to plants in the Asteraceae/Compositae family
growingInformation: Artichokes prefer temperate climates and well-drained soil. They thrive in full sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Artichokes are harvested during the spring. Leaves and roots can be harvested for medicinal use.
shelfLife: Dried artichoke leaf can last up to 2 years if stored correctly.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place. Store capsules according to manufacturer's instructions.
interactionsWithMedications: Diuretics
Medications for bile duct obstruction

name: Senna
preparationMethods: Steep 1 teaspoon dried Senna leaves in 2 cups hot water for 10 minutes
cautions: Use sparingly to prevent dependency
Avoid during pregnancy or breastfeeding
sourceReferences: Mills S, Bone K. The Essential Guide to Herbal Safety. St. Louis, MO. Elsevier Churchill Livingstone, 2005.
National Institutes of Health. Senna - An overview, 2020.

harvestingInfo.method: Harvest leaves and pods when they are fully matured

dosageInfo.elderly: Start with 15 mg daily and adjust as needed

name: Cascara Sagrada
properties: Increases muscle contractions in the intestines
preparationMethods: Consumed as a dried bark extract
cautions: Not for long-term use
Overuse can lead to dependency and decreased bowel function
growingInformation: Prefers light sandy and medium loamy soils. Can grow in nutritionally poor soil.
harvestingInformation: The bark is harvested in the spring or early summer and dried before use.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Diuretic medications
Corticosteroids

name: Blackberry Leaf
uses: Helps alleviate symptoms of mild diarrhea
growingInformation: Thrives in full sun or semi-shade in well-drained soil. Ideal for USDA Zones 5-8.
harvestingInformation: Leaves are best harvested in summer before the plant has fruited.
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container away from sunlight and humidity
interactionsWithMedications: None known, but consult your healthcare provider if you're taking prescription medication
preparationMethods: Steep 1 tablespoon dried Blackberry Leaf in 2 cups hot water for 15 minutes
cautions: None specified, but consult a healthcare provider for extended use
sourceReferences: The New Healing Herbs: The Essential Guide to More Than 130 of Nature's Most Potent Herbal Remedies by Michael Castleman

name: Raspberry Leaf
cautions: Generally considered safe, but consult a healthcare provider if pregnant
Some individuals may experience allergic reactions
growingInformation: Raspberry plants grow best in regions with cool summers and relatively mild winters. They prefer well-drained, sandy loam soils with a pH between 5.6 and 6.2.
harvestingInformation: Leaves can be harvested throughout the growing season, but are best collected in early spring or late fall. Use scissors or a knife to cut leaves, leaving enough leaf material for the plant to continue growing.

dosageInformation.adult: Tea: 1 - 2 teaspoons dried leaf per cup of water, up to 3 times daily.
dosageInformation.elderly: Tea: 1 teaspoon dried leaf per cup of water, once or twice daily.

shelfLife: Dried leaves can be stored up to 2 years in a cool, dark, dry place
storageInstructions: Store dried leaves in an airtight container in a cool, dark, dry place. Avoid extreme temperatures and direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulants and antiplatelet drugs. Consult a healthcare provider before use.

name: Oat Bran
growingInformation: Oats prefer cool, damp conditions and are typically sown in spring or early summer. They need full sun and well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Oat bran is harvested when the oats are mature and the seeds have formed. The hull is then separated from the rest of the grain to create oat bran.

dosageInformation.adult: 20-40g per day mixed with meals or drinks
dosageInformation.elderly: Same as adult dose, unless advised otherwise by physician

shelfLife: Kept in an airtight container, oat bran can last up to 12 months
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May reduce absorption of certain medication if taken simultaneously
preparationMethods: Mixed with psyllium husk in a daily fiber drink
cautions: None specified
sourceReferences: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, Volume 69, Issue 1, January 1999, Pages 30–42
The Journal of Nutrition, Volume 129, Issue 7, July 1999, Pages 1455S–1460S

name: Fermented Ginger
preparationMethods: Fermentation process transforms it into a probiotic food
cautions: Generally safe, but excessive consumption may lead to gastrointestinal discomfort
People with gallstones should consult their doctor before consuming
growingInformation: A tropical plant that prefers part shade and moist, rich, well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest ginger when the plant begins to die back, typically 8-10 months after planting

dosageInformation.elderly: Lower dosage, usually around 1 gram per day

shelfLife: Fermented ginger can last up to 1 year when refrigerated
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight jar in the refrigerator
interactionsWithMedications: May increase the risk of bleeding if taken with blood thinners
May lower blood sugar too much if taken with diabetes medications

name: Fermented Garlic
preparationMethods: Consumed in food or as a supplement
cautions: May cause bad breath or body odor
Individuals with garlic sensitivity should avoid
High doses can lead to stomach disturbances
growingInformation: Prefers full sun and rich, well-draining soil. Typically planted in the fall and harvested in the summer.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the lower leaves begin to brown and the garlic bulb is firm to touch.

dosageInformation.adult: One clove per day in food
dosageInformation.elderly: One clove per day in food

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinning medications

name: Triphala
cautions: Pregnant women should avoid
May cause diarrhea or abdominal discomfort if consumed in high doses
partsUsed: Fruits of three plants: Amla, Bibhitaki and Haritaki
growthInformation: Grows in tropical climates, most common in India
harvestInformation: Fruits are harvested in autumn and dried

dosageInformation.elderly: Start with lower doses, consult a health practitioner

shelfLife: Up to 2 years if stored correctly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight

interactionsWithMedications.Any medications: Might interfere with blood thinning medications
interactionsWithMedications.Recommendation: Consult a health practitioner before combining with other medications

name: Black Walnut and Wormwood
preparationMethods: Capsules filled with a mixture of Black Walnut Hull and Wormwood powders
Tea infusion made from dried Black Walnut and Wormwood
cautions: May interact with certain medications or conditions; consult a healthcare provider before use. Contraindicated in pregnancy or if you have kidney disease.
sourceReferences: European Herbal & Traditional Medicine Practitioners Association
growingInfo: Black Walnut: North American regions, rich soil in sun. Wormwood: Drought resistant, full sun, well-drained soil.
harvestingInfo: Hull of Black Walnut: September. Wormwood: Just before or during flowering in summer.
activeConstituents: Juglone, Tannins, Iodine in Black Walnut. Absinthin, Anabsinthine in Wormwood.
dosageInformation: Adults: 500 mg capsule 1-3 times daily with meals. Children and elderly: Seek advice from healthcare provider.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Store away from children.
interactions: Possible interaction with anticoagulants and antiplatelet drugs due to high tannin content in Black Walnut.

name: Licorice Root and Marshmallow

growingInformation.licoriceRoot: Grows best in deep valleys, sunny and well-drained environment
growingInformation.marshmallow: Grows in damp and saline environments

harvestingInformation.licoriceRoot: Roots should be harvested in the autumn of the fourth or fifth year
harvestingInformation.marshmallow: Roots are best harvested in late autumn or early spring

dosageInformation.adults: 1-2 teaspoons of powder blend in water, taken three times daily before meals

preparationMethods: Powder mixed and taken in warm water before meals
cautions: Licorice root may cause issues with blood pressure or interact with medications when used in large amounts or for extended periods
sourceReferences: Bensky, D., Clavey, S., Stoger, E. (2004). Chinese Herbal Medicine: Materia Medica, 3rd Edition. Eastland Press, Inc. ISBN 978-0939616428.
Chevallier, A. (1996). The Encyclopedia of Medicinal Plants. DK Publishing Inc. ISBN-13: 978-0789410672.
storageInstructions: Store in cool, dry place out of direct sunlight

interactions.medications: Potassium-depleting diuretics, corticosteroids, and heart medications
interactions.conditions: High blood pressure, liver disease, kidney disease

name: Chamomile, Lavender, and Lemon Balm
preparationMethods: Tea steeped with dried flowers and leaves of Chamomile, Lavender, and Lemon Balm
cautions: May cause drowsiness; avoid driving or operating heavy machinery after consumption
Pregnant women and those who are allergic to plants from the Asteraceae/Compositae family (such as ragweed, marigolds, daisies, and chrysanthemums) should avoid Chamomile
Lavender oil can be toxic if taken orally
Lemon Balm might cause too much drowsiness if combined with sedative medications (CNS depressants)
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: All three herbs prefer full sun but can tolerate part shade
Chamomile is a self-seeding annual, Lavender and Lemon Balm are perennial plants
harvestingInformation: Harvest Chamomile flowers when they are fully open, Lavender just before flowers open, and Lemon Balm leaves just before or during blooming
activeConstituents: Linalool, linalyl acetate, terpinen-4-ol, and camphor (Lavender)
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: Sedative medications (CNS depressants)
Drugs like cyclosporine, medication changed by the liver, glaucoma medications

name: Dandelion Root and Artichoke Leaf
properties: Bitter herbs that stimulate bile production and digestive enzyme release
preparationMethods: Capsules filled with a mixture of Dandelion Root and Artichoke Leaf powders
cautions: Consult a healthcare provider before use if you have gallbladder disease or a bile duct obstruction
Should not be taken during pregnancy or breastfeeding without medical advice
growingInformation: Dandelions are perennial plants, can grow in most climates and soil types. Artichoke is a perennial thistle, prefers well-drained soil and full sun.
harvestingInformation: Dandelion roots are harvested in the fall, artichoke leaves are harvested just before the flower buds fully open.
activeConstituents: Inulin, bitter glycosides, flavonoids, phenolic acids, essential oil, tannins for Dandelion Root; Cynarin, flavonoids, phenolic acids for Artichoke Leaf.
dosageInformation: Adults: 500-1500 mg of the blend per day; Children and Elderly: Consult a healthcare provider
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with diuretics, anticoagulants, lithium and certain antibiotics. Consult health professional before use.

name: Slippery Elm and Plantain
properties: Provides mucilage that protects mucous membranes of the digestive tract
preparationMethods: Powder mixed and taken in warm water before meals
cautions: Slippery Elm may interfere with the absorption of certain medications
sourceReferences: The University of Maryland Medical Center
WebMD article on health benefits of Slippery Elm

growingInformation.Slippery Elm: Prefers partial to full sun exposure and moist, well-drained soil
growingInformation.Plantain: Grows well in varied conditions, including full sun or partial shade and dry or wet soils

harvestingInformation.Plantain: Harvest leaves throughout growing season, seeds in late summer

dosageInformation.adult: One to two teaspoonfuls of powder mixed in warm water before meals

storageInstructions: Keep in sealed container, in cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May delay absorption of other drugs if taken at the same time
Consult with a healthcare provider before combining with prescribed medications

name: Peppermint and Ginger
preparationMethods: Capsules filled with a mixture of Peppermint and Ginger powders
cautions: Peppermint may cause heartburn in some individuals; avoid if you have GERD. Ginger should not be consumed in large doses during pregnancy.
growingInformation: Peppermint: Grows best in damp shaded areas and has a spreading habit.
Ginger: Prefers filtered sunlight and rich, moist, fertile soil.
harvestingInformation: Peppermint: Harvest just as flowering begins.
Ginger: Harvest root after plant dies down in late summer to early fall.
dosageInformation: Adults: 1-2 capsules daily
Children: Consult a doctor
Elderly: 1 capsule daily
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with antacids, medication for stomach acid, blood thinners, and diabetes medication.

name: Valerian and Skullcap
properties: Calming nervine herbs that reduce anxiety and promote restful sleep
uses: Mitigating symptoms of withdrawal from addictive substances
preparationMethods: Capsules filled with a mixture of Valerian Root and Skullcap powders
Tea made from Valerian root and/or Skullcap leaves
cautions: May cause drowsiness; avoid driving or operating heavy machinery.
Consult a healthcare provider before use if pregnant, nursing, or on medication
Do not take if you are currently taking sedatives or sleep aids
sourceReferences: National Institutes of Health, Office of Dietary Supplements
Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine
plantFamily: Mint family or Lamiaceae for Skullcap
partsUsed: Leaves and small parts of Skullcap
growingInformation: Both herbs prefer full sun to partial shade and well-draining soil
Valerian is a perennial plant while Skullcap is an annual plant
harvestingInformation: Valerian roots are harvested in the fall of their second year
Skullcap leaves are harvested in summer when the plant is in bloom
activeConstituents: Flavonoids and phenolic compounds in Skullcap

dosageInformation.adult: 300-600 mg per day for anxiety and stress, up to 2 g for sleep disorders
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with a lower dose due to increased sensitivity, consult with healthcare provider

shelfLife: Up to 2 years when stored in ideal conditions
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Keep away from direct sunlight
interactions: May increase the effects of sedatives and sleep-aid drugs
May interact with certain anti-anxiety medications
Taking Valerian with other herbs that cause sleepiness may lead to excessive sleepiness
Avoid in combination with other herbs that have blood-thinning properties

name: Meadowsweet
properties: May ease symptoms of stomach upset
uses: Used in tea for pain relief
Used in herbal medicine to soothe stomach symptoms
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water for tea
cautions: Should be avoided by individuals with aspirin allergies
Excessive use may cause stomach upset
Pregnant women should avoid use due to potential uterine stimulation
sourceReferences: Grieve, M. (1996). A Modern Herbal. Dover Publications.
Barker, J. (2001). The Medicinal Flora of Britain and Northwestern Europe. Winter Press.
growingInformation: Prefers moist, well-drained soils in full sun to partial shade. Frost tolerant.
harvestingInformation: Harvest flowers in late spring to early summer, leaves and stems throughout growing season.

dosageInformation.adult: 2-4 ml of tincture three times daily, or 1-2 teaspoons dried herb in tea
dosageInformation.children: Proportional dosage based on weight, consult a healthcare practitioner
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with lower dosage, adjust as needed

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place away from direct sunlight. Do not use if the smell has significantly faded or the color has changed.
interactionsWithMedications: May enhance the effects of anticoagulants and other blood-thinning medications

name: Beet
preparationMethods: Blend with dandelion greens, berries, ginger, and coconut water in a smoothie
Can be consumed as juice or in raw, cooked, pickled, and powdered forms
cautions: High consumption can temporarily change urine color
People with kidney disease may need to limit beet consumption due to high oxalate content
growingInformation: In well-drained soil rich in organic matter, with full sun exposure. Grow in cool seasons.
harvestingInformation: Usually harvested 60-70 days after planting when roots are up to 3 inches wide.
activeConstituents: Betaine, Fiber, Folate, Manganese, Potassium, Iron, Vitamin C

dosageInformation.children: Half a beet daily depending on age and size
dosageInformation.elderly: 1 beet daily, unless advised differently by a healthcare professional

shelfLife: Can last up to 2 weeks in the refrigerator with the greens removed
storageInstructions: Remove greens and store in a plastic bag in the refrigerator. Do not wash until ready to use.
interactionsWithMedications: May lower blood sugar levels, affecting diabetes medications; can interact with blood pressure medications due to potential to lower blood pressure.

name: Schisandra Berries
cautions: May cause heartburn and stomach upset
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
growingInformation: Prefers slightly acidic, well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight. Perennial vine that can grow up to 25 feet.
harvestingInformation: Harvest in late summer or early autumn when berries are fully ripe.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Avoid direct sunlight and moisture.
interactions: Can interfere with drugs metabolized by liver or increase effect of sedatives.

name: Thistle
uses: Part of a tincture for promoting liver health
Can be used to treat cirrhosis, jaundice, hepatitis, and gallbladder disorders.
preparationMethods: Can also be consumed as a tea or in capsule form
cautions: Specific cautions not mentioned, but general caution advised when using potent herbs
May interact with certain medications, including diabetes medication and drugs broken down by the liver
growingInformation: Thistles prefer dry and sunny conditions. They are resistant to drought.
harvestingInformation: Seeds should be harvested in late summer, when the flower has fully bloomed and begun to dry out.
dosageInformation: Adults: 140 mg of silymarin (active ingredient in milk thistle) three times daily; Children: Consult a healthcare provider
shelfLife: Three years sealed and up to one year after opening if stored correctly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, out of reach of children.
interactionsWithMedications: Can interact with diabetes medication and drugs broken down by the liver. Consult a healthcare provider if on medications before starting any herbal supplements.

name: Dill
uses: Added to vegetable ferments to improve digestive health
Can aid in reducing menstrual cramps
preparationMethods: Can be used fresh or dried in culinary preparations and fermentations
Can be made into a tea
cautions: None specified, but individuals with allergies to plants in the Apiaceae family should proceed with caution
growingInformation: Dill prefers to grow in full sun and well-drained soil. It can be sown outdoors in spring after the danger of frost has passed.
harvestingInformation: Leaves may be harvested anytime during the growing season. To harvest seeds, allow the plant to flower and wait until the seed clusters turn brown.
shelfLife: Fresh dill should be used within 1-2 days, while dried dill can be stored for 4-6 months.
storageInstructions: Store fresh dill in the refrigerator. Dried dill should be stored in a cool, dark place in an airtight container.

interactions.medications: May interact with medications that affect blood clotting, such as warfarin.

name: Hoodia Gordonii
properties: contains compound P57 which affects the hypothalamus
uses: Traditionally used to suppress hunger during long hunting trips
Used as a natural weight loss supplement
preparationMethods: Can be brewed into a tea
cautions: Safety and efficacy for long-term use are not well documented
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
tags: Not for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Publication: Hoodia gordonii in the treatment of obesity: A review (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ptr.2658)
growingInformation: Full sun exposure and well-drained soil. Drought-tolerant.
harvestingInformation: Harvest mature stems from adult plants.

dosageInformation.elderly: Use with caution, potential interactions with other medications

storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May affect glucose metabolism and cardiac function, consult a healthcare provider if you have diabetes or heart disease.

name: Garcinia Cambogia
cautions: May interact with medications, including those for diabetes and cholesterol

harvestingInformation.season: Due to tropical nature, fruit can be harvested year-round

dosageInformation.adult: 500mg three times per day, 30-60 minutes before meals
dosageInformation.elderly: 500mg two times per day, 30-60 minutes before meals

storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark, and dry place
interactionsWithMedications: May interfere with medications for diabetes and cholesterol
Should not be taken with prescription medications without consulting a healthcare provider

name: Fennel Seed
uses: Promotes a feeling of fullness. Consuming before meals can help curb appetite and reduce overeating
preparationMethods: Can also be used as a spice in cooking
growingInformation: Full sun, well-drained soil, suitable for container gardening
harvestingInformation: Harvest seeds in late summer when they turn brown
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactions: May interact with Tamoxifen, ovarian cancer drugs

name: Gymnema Sylvestre
uses: Beneficial for those with sugar cravings or difficulty maintaining a healthy diet.
Can aid in the management of type 2 diabetes.
preparationMethods: Dried leaves can be steeped in tea for appetite suppression.
cautions: Should not be taken by pregnant or breastfeeding women. Should be used with caution by individuals with diabetes or on medication, as it may dramatically decrease blood sugar levels.
sourceReferences: Shanmugasundaram, E. R. (2005). Possible regeneration of the islets of Langerhans in streptozotocin-diabetic rats given Gymnema sylvestre leaf extracts. Journal of Ethnopharmacology
growing information: Grows best in tropical regions in well-drained soil with full sun exposure.
harvesting information: Harvest leaves when plant is mature and dry.
storage instructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactions with medications: Can interfere with blood sugar-lowering medications.

name: Green Tea Extract
uses: Effective for appetite control and weight loss
Reduces appetite and increases metabolism when consumed before meals
preparationMethods: Can be consumed as tea or in capsule form before meals
cautions: Contains caffeine, which may not be suitable for everyone. Pregnant or breastfeeding women and people with heart conditions should consult a health professional before use.
growingInformation: Grows best in tropical and subtropical climates with well-draining acid soil. Requires full sun or partial shade.
harvestingInformation: The young leaves and buds are typically harvested by hand in the spring.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place, away from humidity.

name: Caralluma Fimbriata
properties: Influences hunger-regulating hormones, including reducing ghrelin levels.
uses: Used in traditional Indian medicine for treating conditions like rheumatism and diabetes.
preparationMethods: Caralluma Fimbriata can be consumed raw or cooked like a vegetable, and is also available in capsule form.
cautions: Excessive consumption may cause stomach upset. Pregnant and nursing mothers should avoid use.
sourceReferences: Kuriyan, R., et al., (2007). Effect of Caralluma fimbriata extract on appetite, food intake and anthropometry in adult Indian men and women. Appetite, 48(3), 338-344.
growingInformation: Caralluma Fimbriata is a succulent plant that grows in arid regions of India. Prefers sandy soil and full sun exposure.
harvestingInformation: Stems are harvested in the late summer to early autumn once they mature.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May enhance the effects of anti-diabetic and anti-hypertensive drugs.

name: Slippery Elm and Marshmallow Root
properties: Mucilaginous herbs that create a soothing, gelatinous texture when combined with water.
uses: Coat the stomach and promote a feeling of satiety, reducing hunger and managing appetite.
Soothe irritation in the stomach, throat and urinary tract.
preparationMethods: Typically consumed in the form of tea or supplements.
cautions: Can interfere with the absorption of other medication if taken at the same time.
growingInformation: Hardy plants that prefer full sun and well-drained soil.
harvestingInformation: Inner bark is harvested in spring (Slippery Elm)
Roots are harvested in late autumn or early spring after the plant is  two years old (Marshmallow Root).
dosageInformation: Adults: 1-2 grams of the powdered bark or root up to 3 times daily
Children: Consult a health professional
Elderly: Start with a lower dose
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Can interfere with the absorption of other medications if taken simultaneously.

name: Bitter Melon
uses: Reduces hunger spikes and prevents cravings for sugary foods by balancing blood sugar levels.
Used traditionally for treating various infections and diseases like diabetes, cancer, and wounds.
preparationMethods: Commonly used in Asian cuisine in soups, teas, or eaten raw as a vegetable.
Can be taken in supplement form for appetite and blood sugar control.
cautions: Bitter melon should be used under the supervision of a health professional due to its strong effect on blood sugar levels.
Should be avoided during pregnancy and breastfeeding.
growingInformation: Tropical and subtropical climates. Requires well-drained soil and plenty of sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the fruit is green and firm. Overripe fruits are excessively bitter.

dosageInformation.adult: 1/2 - 1 cup of juice daily or 2-3 small melons as part of a meal.
dosageInformation.children: Use under the supervision of a health professional
dosageInformation.elderly: 1/3 - 1/2 cup juice daily, depending on the individual's blood sugar levels.

shelfLife: Store fresh bitter melon in the refrigerator for up to 1 week. Dried slices and powdered forms can last up to 2 years.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Do not wash until ready to use.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with glucose-lowering medication and cause hypoglycemia.

name: Gymnema
preparationMethods: Included in the Cinnamon and Gymnema Appetite-Suppressing Tea preparation
Infused in hot water as tea
cautions: May lower blood sugar levels too much in combination with diabetes medications
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: Gymnema Sylvestre in the treatment of Diabetes Mellitus - An Evidence Based Review, Phytotherapy Research, 2018
Effects of a Gymnema Sylvestre on glucose homeostasis: A systematic review and meta-analysis, PloS One, 2018
growingInformation: Requires warm tropical climate. Propagated from seeds or cuttings in well-drained soil with full to partial sunlight.
harvestingInformation: Leaves should be harvested when the plant is 2 years old during the dry season.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Avoid use in combination with diabetes medications due to potential for hypoglycemia

name: Hoodia
uses: Used in capsule form to help reduce hunger before meals.
May help in the management of weight.
preparationMethods: Mix Hoodia powder with Fenugreek powder, fill empty gel capsules, and take 1 capsule up to twice daily before meals.
cautions: None mentioned, but its safety and efficacy for long-term use have not been well studied.
People with diabetes, heart issues, or taking certain medication should consult their healthcare provider before using Hoodia.
sourceReferences: WebMD. (n.d.). Hoodia: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Dosage, and Warning. www.webmd.com
Chevallier, A. (1996). The Encyclopedia of Medicinal Plants. Dorling Kindersley.
growingInformation: Prefers arid climates with well-draining soil. Requires full sunlight and infrequent watering.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when the plant is mature, generally after the second year of growth.

dosageInformation.adult: 1 capsule up to twice daily before meals

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place out of reach of children. Ensure the container is sealed tightly.
interactions: Diabetes medication
Anticoagulant medication
Blood pressure medication

name: Marshmallow
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water for teas
cautions: Limited, but may interfere with the absorption of other medications
Not recommended for pregnant or breastfeeding women
sourceReferences: European Medicines Agency (2010). Assessment report on Althaea officinalis L., Radix. London: EMA.
National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health. Marshmallow. Bethesda, MD: National Institutes of Health.
growingInformation: Prefers moist, well-drained soil in full to partial sun exposure. Hardy in zones 3-9.
harvestingInformation: Roots are harvested in the fall after the plant is at least two years old. Leaves are harvested before blooming in summer.

dosageInformation.adult: 2-5g root daily or 5-10ml of tincture three times daily
dosageInformation.children: Use under the guidance of a healthcare provider
dosageInformation.elderly: Use under the guidance of a healthcare provider

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from light. Keep out of reach of children.
interactions: May delay absorption of concurrently taken oral medications.

name: Quercetin and Bromelain
properties: Quercetin stabilizes mast cells to prevent histamine release
uses: Effective for managing seasonal and food-related allergies by reducing allergy symptoms
Shown to assist overall immune health
preparationMethods: Combine with alcohol in a glass jar, let steep for 4-6 weeks, strain, and store in a dark glass bottle
cautions: Alcohol-based tinctures may not be suitable for everyone; consult a healthcare provider if unsure
Do not use while on anticoagulant medications without talking to your doctor
plantFamily: Not applicable – compounds found in various plants
partsUsed: Quercetin is typically derived from onions or apples. Bromelain comes from the stem or fruit of the pineapple plant.
growingInformation: Not applicable - compounds extracted from grown plants
harvestingInformation: Onions/apples for Quercetin are harvested when ripe. Pineapples for Bromelain are harvested when fruit is fully matured.

dosageInformation.adult: 500mg with meals, three times a day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulant/antiplatelet drugs, antibiotics, certain cancer medications, and other substances. Always consult with a healthcare provider before use.

name: Licorice Root and Calendula
uses: Soothing allergy-related skin conditions by reducing redness and calming irritated skin
May alleviate gastric symptoms like heartburn and stomach ulcers
preparationMethods: Infuse in olive oil over low heat
cautions: Licorice root may increase blood pressure if taken in large quantities
Avoid using it if you have heart disease or hormonal-related issues.
sourceReferences: Licorice Root and Calendula: A study of their properties - Journal of Herbal Medicine, 2010
The Healing Power of Licorice Root and Calendula - The Herb Companion, 2012

growingInformation.Licorice Root: Can be grown in well-drained soils, prefers full sun
growingInformation.Calendula: Prefers sunny locations, grows easily from seeds

harvestingInformation.Licorice Root: Roots can be harvested in the third or fourth year of growth
harvestingInformation.Calendula: Flowers are best harvested in summer and dried for use

dosage.adults: Licorice Root: Do not exceed 5g per day, Calendula: Use as directed on package
dosage.elderly: Use with caution, may interact with several medications

storageInstructions.Licorice Root: Store in a cool, dark place in an airtight container
storageInstructions.Calendula: Store in a cool, dark place in an airtight container

interactionsWithMedications.Licorice Root: May interact with medications like blood thinners, blood pressure medication, steroid-based drugs
interactionsWithMedications.Calendula: Generally safe but can possibly interact with sedative drugs

name: Butterbur and Nettle
uses: Effective for managing allergy-related respiratory symptoms
Can be used to alleviate symptoms of hay fever and asthma
cautions: Butterbur may cause liver damage if not properly processed
ensure sourcing from a reputable supplier
sourceReferences: The American Journal of Medicine, Volume 118, Issue 12, December 2005, Pages 1344-1351

growingInformation.Butterbur: Prefers moist conditions, and grows well in shady or partially shaded areas.
growingInformation.Nettle: Thrives in nitrogen-rich soil and full sun or partial shade.

harvestingInformation.Butterbur: Roots are harvested in late autumn or early spring.
harvestingInformation.Nettle: Leaves are best harvested in spring and can be used fresh or dried.

dosageInformation.adult: Butterbur extract: 50-75 mg twice a day, Nettle extract: 300 mg/day

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Consult with a doctor if you are taking any other medications

name: Reishi and Holy Basil
properties: Adaptogenic herbs that balance the body's stress response
uses: Ideal for managing stress-induced allergy symptoms
Beneficial in supporting stress management and mental clarity
preparationMethods: Steep in hot water for 15 minutes, strain, and serve warm
cautions: Reishi may interact with certain medications; consult a healthcare provider if on medication
Avoid usage if pregnant, nursing or have active liver disease

growingInformation.Reishi: Grows on decaying hardwood trees in warm, humid, coastal areas
growingInformation.Holy Basil: Prefers full sun, rich soil, and regular watering. It is a tropical plant

harvestingInformation.Reishi: Harvest mature fruiting bodies in summer
harvestingInformation.Holy Basil: Harvest leaves and seeds in late summer

activeConstituents.Holy Basil: Eugenol, ursolic acid, rosmarinic acid, oleanolic acid

dosageInformation.adult: 3-5 grams of dried reishi, 2-4 grams of dried holy basil

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: Reishi may interact with anticoagulants, immunosuppressants, hepatotoxic drugs. Holy Basil might slow blood clotting.

name: Turmeric and Licorice
properties: Potent anti-inflammatory properties that support liver health and promote immune balance.
uses: Could be beneficial in maintaining a healthy liver.
preparationMethods: Mix powders, fill empty capsules, and seal.
cautions: Turmeric may thin the blood; avoid taking with blood thinners.
Excessive consumption of licorice can lead to high blood pressure.

growingInformation.turmeric: Tropical climate, well-drained soil, moderate sunlight.
growingInformation.licorice: Sandy and loamy soils, sufficient sunlight, can survive in dry areas.

harvestingInformation.licorice: Roots harvested in the third or fourth year.

dosageInformation.elderly: Dose may need to be reduced depending on overall health and medication.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with blood thinning medications
May affect medications for high blood pressure due to licorice.

name: Dandelion and Burdock
cautions: May interact with diuretics
May interact with diabetes medication
growingInformation: Dandelion and Burdock grow in a wide range of climates, prefer full sun and well-draining soil. Both can be sown directly outdoors in spring.
harvestingInformation: The roots are harvested in the fall of their second year, while leaves can be harvested anytime during the growing season.
activeConstituents: Inulin, flavonoids, volatile oils, plant sterols, tannins
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.

interactions.generalGuidelines: Always consult with your healthcare provider before starting any new supplement regimen.

name: Chamomile and Ginger
preparationMethods: Steep dried flowers and root in hot water, strain, and serve
cautions: Chamomile may cause allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to the daisy family
Ginger may interact with certain medications, consult your healthcare provider before use.
sourceReferences: Herbal Medicine: Expanded Commission E Monographs
The Complete German Commission E Monographs, Therapeutic Guide to Herbal Medicines

growingInformation.Chamomile: Thrives in full sun or partial shade in well-drained soil, annual plant.
growingInformation.Ginger: Thrives in warm climates, well-draining rich soil, can be grown indoors in cooler climates.

harvestingInformation.Chamomile: Harvest when flowers are fully open, dry them in a dark airy place
harvestingInformation.Ginger: Harvest roots in late summer to fall, when the plant begins to die back.

dosageInformation.Adult: 1-2 teaspoons steeped in boiling water, up to 4 times daily
dosageInformation.Children: Consult healthcare provider for correct dosage
dosageInformation.Elderly: 1 teaspoon steeped in boiling water, up to 4 times daily

shelfLife.Dried chamomile flowers and ginger root: Up to 3 years when stored properly

storageInstructions.Both: Store in a cool, dark, dry place in airtight containers

interactionsWithMedications.Ginger: May interact with blood thinners, diabetes medications, and high blood pressure drugs

name: Oatmeal
uses: Treatment for dry and itchy skin
preparationMethods: Ground and mixed with honey and Chamomile
Steeped in hot water and applied as a poultice
cautions: Avoid contact with eyes
Do not use on broken or highly sensitive skin
sourceReferences: Journal of Drugs in Dermatology: Oatmeal in Dermatology: A Brief Review
Archives of Dermatological Research: Colloidal Oatmeal: History, Chemistry and Clinical Properties
growingInformation: Oats are a type of cereal grain that's grown in temperate regions. They require well-drained soil and full sun exposure.
harvestingInformation: Oats are harvested in the early maturing stages while the grains are still green and soft.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight

name: Rhodiola Rosea
preparationMethods: Tinctures to combat fatigue and enhance mental clarity
cautions: May cause dizziness
Dry mouth in some individuals
Should not be used by pregnant or nursing mothers, and individuals with bipolar disorder
growingInformation: Prefers sandy, well-drained soils. Can tolerate cold climates, typically found in high altitude areas in Northern Hemisphere.
harvestingInformation: Roots are harvested in the fall when most potent.

dosageInformation.children: Not recommended for children under 12 years
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with lower dose (50-100mg daily) and adjust as necessary

shelfLife: Three to four years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dark, and dry place. Keep away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with antidepressant or anti-anxiety medications, and other substances that affect the central nervous system.

name: Bergamot
uses: Reduces anxiety when used in a diffuser or applied topically
Used in massage therapy for its calming effects
Often used in perfumery and skincare products for its unique citrusy scent and beneficial properties
preparationMethods: Diluted in a carrier oil for topical application
Used in balms and skin creams
cautions: Topical use should be sun-safe
Bergamot can be photosensitizing
Avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding
May cause skin irritation in some individuals; a patch test should be done before full use
sourceReferences: Aromatherapy: A Complete Guide to the Healing Art by Kathi Keville and Mindy Green
Essential Oil Safety: A Guide for Health Care Professionals by Robert Tisserand and Rodney Young
dilutionRatios: 1-2% essential oil in a carrier oil for topical use
safetyPrecautions: Avoid exposure to the sun or tanning beds for 12-24 hours after applying bergamot oil onto the skin
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from sunlight. Keep the bottle cap tightly closed when not in use

name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)
preparationMethods: Mix powder with rhodiola powder, fill capsules
Can be brewed into a tea
cautions: May lower blood sugar levels, caution advised for those with diabetes
Pregnant and breastfeeding women should consult their healthcare provider
sourceReferences: Gupta S, Mediratta PK, Singh S, Sharma KK, Shukla R (2012). 'Antidiabetic, antihypercholesterolaemic and antioxidant effect of Ocimum sanctum (Linn) seed oil.'
Cohen MM (2014). 'Tulsi - Ocimum sanctum: A herb for all reasons.'
growingInformation: Tulsi prefers rich, well-drained soil with full sun exposure. It grows 2-3 ft tall and flowers in mid to late summer. It germinates in 1-2 weeks and can be harvested approximately 40 days after planting.
harvestingInformation: The leaves and seeds of tulsi plant can be harvested in the mid to late summer when they are at the peak of their potency.

dosageInformation.adult: 500mg to 2g of dried leaf daily. Adjust based on stress levels.

shelfLife: Dried Tulsi can be stored for up to two years when stored properly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place. Keep away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with antidiabetic drugs due to potential to lower blood sugar levels. Consult with a healthcare provider.

name: Saffron
uses: Used in a vision-enhancing tea with Chamomile
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water with Chamomile
cautions: High doses can be toxic; use in moderation.
Not recommended for pregnant women due to potential uterine stimulation.
growingInformation: Prefers full sun and well-drained soil. Generally grown in Mediterranean climates.
harvestingInformation: Harvested in the fall when flowers are in full bloom.
shelfLife: Up to 4 years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, dry place
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulants
Antihypertensives

name: Bacopa Monnieri
properties: Supports memory retention and cognitive processing.
uses: Drunk as a tea to promote mental clarity and enhance learning.
Applied topically to promote skin health.
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water for tea.
Crushed and mixed with a carrier oil for topical application.
cautions: May interact with certain medications and cause gastrointestinal upset.
Do not use if pregnant or breastfeeding without consulting your doctor.
growingInfo: This plant prefers wet, marshy areas, and takes approximately three months to mature.
harvestingInfo: Harvest leaves and stems during the late summer or early fall when the plant is mature.

dosageInfo.adult: 300-450 mg daily, under the supervision of a healthcare professional.
dosageInfo.elderly: Lower dose, 150-300 mg daily, under the supervision of a healthcare professional.

shelfLife: Dried herb can last up to 2 years if stored correctly.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with sedatives, antidepressants, and medications for Alzheimer's disease.

name: Lion’s Mane Mushroom
properties: Stimulates nerve growth factor (NGF) supporting neuron health and regeneration.
uses: Gaining popularity for its potential to maintain cognitive health and memory.
Used to support overall mental function and defend against age-related cognitive decline.
preparationMethods: Specific methods not mentioned, but available in various forms including powders, supplements, and teas.
cautions: Generally considered safe, but potential interactions with medications or conditions should be reviewed. Not recommend for those allergic to mushrooms.
growingInformation: Grows naturally on hardwood trees in temperate forests of North America, Europe, and Asia.
harvestingInformation: Harvested when mature in late summer and early fall.

dosageInformation.adult: 1000 - 3000 mg per day, split in two doses
dosageInformation.elderly: Contact healthcare provider for dosage instructions.

shelfLife: Up to 1 year if stored in proper conditions.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place, away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Could interact with blood-thinning and blood sugar-lowering medications.

name: Lion’s Mane
uses: Used in cognitive-boosting capsules for mental clarity
May help to alleviate symptoms of depression and anxiety
preparationMethods: Can also be incorporated into food dishes or brewed into a tea
cautions: May cause mild digestive issues in some individuals
May lead to a rash or itchy skin in some individuals
growingInformation: Prefers temperate forests and is commonly found on hardwoods.
harvestingInformation: Best harvested in the fall when the fruiting body is fresh and young.
shelfLife: Generally, the dried powder can be stored for up to two years.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light and moisture.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs

name: Brahmi
uses: Used in hair nourishing oils to strengthen hair
Helps to improve memory and cognitive function
preparationMethods: Simmer Brahmi powder in sesame oil, strain, and store
Can be infused in tea or taken in capsule form for cognitive benefits
cautions: None specified
Consult with a doctor before use if pregnant, nursing, or on any medications
sourceReferences: Stough C, et al. The chronic effects of an extract of Bacopa monniera (Brahmi) on cognitive function in healthy human subjects. Psychopharmacology. 2001;156(4):481–4.
Sharath R, Harish BG, Krishna V, Sathyanarayana BN, Swamy H. Hair growth promoting activity of Eclipta alba in male albino rats. Arch Dermatol Res. 2008;300(7):357–64.

storageInstructions.driedHerb: Keep in a cool, dry place in airtight containers
storageInstructions.powder: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight

name: Rhodiola Root
properties: Reduces mental fatigue and sharpens focus
uses: Known for its ability to help reduce symptoms of depression
preparationMethods: Powder form, mixed and filled into empty gel capsules
cautions: May cause dry mouth or dizziness in some individuals
It may interact with certain medications such as antidepressants
growingInformation: Rhodiola grows best in cold, mountainous regions. It is a perennial plant with no specific soil requirements.
harvestingInformation: Rhodiola roots are typically harvested in the fall after the plant has had at least 3-5 years of growth.
storageInstructions: Keep in a cool, dry place, away from light and heat.
interactionsWithMedications: May interact with antidepressants
May interact with stimulants

name: Lemon Essential Oil
properties: Promotes sharp focus and mental clarity.
uses: Used in combination with Sage for enhancing mental clarity.
Can be used as a natural disinfectant due to its antimicrobial properties.
preparationMethods: Combined with Sage essential oil in a spray.
May also be diluted in a diffuser for aromatic benefits.
cautions: Should be diluted before use on skin; avoid direct sunlight on areas where applied.
Avoid use during pregnancy or breastfeeding without medical consultation.
extractionMethod: Cold Press Extraction from the lemon peel.
dilutionRatios: Dilute at a 1:1 ratio with a carrier oil for topical application, or 2-3 drops in a diffuser for aromatic benefits.
safetyPrecautions: Always patch test before use on larger skin areas. Avoid contact with eyes and mucous membranes.
shelfLife: Once open, Lemon Essential Oil should be used within 6 to 8 months for maximum benefits.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from direct sunlight and heat sources.

name: Ginkgo
properties: Enhances blood flow to the eyes
uses: Might help in treating symptoms of dementia
preparationMethods: Steeped in hot water with Gotu Kola
cautions: None mentioned. However, it should be taken with care as it may interact with certain medications like anticoagulants, antidepressants, and others.
sourceReferences: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
growingInformation: Ginkgo trees can be grown in full sun or partial shade with well-draining soil. They can reach up to 50-80 feet in height and can live for hundreds of years.
harvestingInformation: Ginkgo leaves are best harvested in the fall when the leaves start to yellow.

dosageInformation.adults: 120-240 mg per day, in divided doses
dosageInformation.elderly: 120-240 mg per day, in divided doses

shelfLife: A sealed container of ginkgo leaves can last for about 1 year. Supplements or extracts have a shelf life of up to 3 years.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight.
interactionsWithMedications: Anticoagulants
Antidepressants

name: Poppy
properties: Useful for reducing sleep latency and encouraging peaceful sleep.
uses: Promotes relaxation and aids in transitioning into sleep.
May help to alleviate symptoms of anxiety.
preparationMethods: Tinctures can be taken about 30 minutes before bedtime.
Poppy seeds can consumed in a variety of culinary dishes.
cautions: Specific cautions were not mentioned, but as with all herbs, it should be used responsibly and with awareness of potential interactions with other medications or conditions.
Not recommended during pregnancy or while breastfeeding.
sourceReferences: Medical Herbalism: The Science and Practice of Herbal Medicine by David Hoffmann
The Herb Book: The Most Complete Catalog of Herbs Ever Published by John Lust
growingInformation: Poppy plants prefers full sun and well-draining soil. It tolerates a range of soil types and pH levels.
harvestingInformation: Harvest poppy seeds when the pods are dry and have begun to turn brown.

dosageInformation.adult: 1-2 teaspoons of poppy seed tincture before bedtime
dosageInformation.elderly: Consult with a healthcare provider before use

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight
interactionsWithMedications: May enhance the sedative effect of CNS depressants and other sleep-inducing medications.

name: Lion's Mane Mushroom
properties: Supports production of nerve growth factor
cautions: Generally well tolerated, but potential interactions with medications have not been thoroughly studied
Not recommended for those with mushroom allergies
Pregnant or breastfeeding women should consult a healthcare provider
interactions: Consult a healthcare provider if on prescribed medication
There may be potential interactions
growingInformation: Grows on hardwood trees in North America, Europe, and Asia.
harvestingInformation: Best harvested in late summer to fall when the fruit body is mature.
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight.

name: Lion's Mane
uses: Helps to manage symptoms of anxiety and depression
cautions: Well-tolerated
May cause gastrointestinal discomfort in some cases
Consult with a healthcare provider before use if pregnant, nursing, or taking other medications
sourceReferences: Li IC, Lee LY, Tzeng TT, et al. Neurohealth Properties of Hericium erinaceus Mycelia Enriched with Erinacines. Behav Neurol. 2018:5802634. https://doi.org/10.1155/2018/5802634

Friedman M. Chemistry, Nutrition, and Health-Promoting Properties of Hericium erinaceus (Lion's Mane) Mushroom Fruiting Bodies and Mycelia and Their Bioactive Compounds. J Agric Food Chem. 2015;63(32):7108–7123. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jafc.5b02914
growingInformation: Grows naturally on hardwoods, particularly American beech. Prefers moist and shady conditions. Cultivated varieties can be grown at home using substrate blocks.
harvestingInformation: Harvest when fruiting bodies are fully mature and spines are visible. Cut at the base with a sharp knife.
shelfLife: Can be stored up to 1 year
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from sunlight. Powdered form must be kept in airtight containers.
interactionsWithMedications: No known significant interactions. Consultation with a healthcare provider is advised if taking other medications.

name: Dong Quai
uses: Effective for women experiencing mood swings due to hormonal fluctuations
Helps in relieving menstrual cramps and managing menopause symptoms
preparationMethods: Commonly used in tinctures or capsules
cautions: None specified
May cause photosensitivity, avoid direct sunlight or UV light
Do not use if pregnant, breastfeeding, or have a bleeding disorder
growingInformation: Prefers cool, shady locations in semi-rich, well-drained soil
harvestingInformation: Harvest roots in autumn after 3 years of growth
shelfLife: Up to 3 years when stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark, and dry place

interactionsWithMedications.Anticoagulant: Increases risk of bleeding or bruising
interactionsWithMedications.Estrogen: May interfere with hormone replacement therapy or birth control

name: Willow Bark
cautions: Should not be used by individuals allergic to aspirin
Should not be used by those under 18 due to the risk of Reye's syndrome
Should not be used during pregnancy
growingInformation: Thrives in moist, well-drained soil in full to partial sun.
harvestingInformation: Bark is harvested in the spring from young branches and twigs.

dosageInformation.adult: 240 mg standardized to 15% salicin, taken 1-2 times a day
dosageInformation.elderly: 240 mg standardized to 15% salicin, taken once a day. Adjust as necessary.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place in an airtight container
interactionsWithMedications: May increase bleeding risk when taken with anticoagulants
May interact with NSAIDs, increasing risk of stomach upset

name: Devil's Claw
properties: Contains harpagoside that has anti-inflammatory effects
preparationMethods: Often paired with other anti-inflammatory herbs in tinctures or capsules
Infused in water for making tea
cautions: Consult a healthcare provider if taking other medications
Avoid during pregnancy and breastfeeding
May cause digestive problems
sourceReferences: Grant, L., McBean,D.E., Fyfe, L., and Warnock, A.M. (2007). A review of the biological and potential therapeutic actions of Harpagophytum procumbens. Phytotherapy Research;21(3):199–209
Chrubasik, S., Zimpfer, C., Schutt, U., and Ziegler, R. (1996). Effectiveness of Harpagophytum procumbens in treatment of acute low back pain. Phytomedicine;3(1): 1–10
growingInformation: Grows in arid regions. Prefers sunny locations and well-drained soils.
harvestingInformation: Harvest the tubers in winter, when the plant's constituents are most potent.
shelfLife: Up to 2 years if properly stored
storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dark place away from moisture
interactionWithOtherMedications: May increase the effects of blood-thinning medications

name: Arnica
uses: Incorporated in a Bone-Healing Balm and Joint-Soothing Cream for pain relief
Commonly used in homeopathy for bruising, swelling, and recovery from traumatic injuries
preparationMethods: Infused in coconut oil or shea butter
cautions: For external use only
can cause irritation or allergic reactions in some individuals
Do not use on open wounds or broken skin
growingInformation: Arnica prefers full sun exposure and well-drained, slightly acidic soil. It blooms in the late spring or early summer.
harvestingInformation: Flower heads are harvested in the summer and dried for medicinal use.
activeConstituents: Helenalin, arnica oil, and other flavonoids

dosageInformation.adults: Typically used topically in 1-3% concentrations, but specific dosage will depend on the formulation used.
dosageInformation.children: Use in children is not recommended due to the risk of skin irritation or allergic reactions.
dosageInformation.elderly: Start with lower concentration and monitor the skin for any reaction.

storageInstructions: Store in a cool, dry place away from light and heat. Ensure that the container is sealed tightly.

interactionsWithMedications.anticoagulants: May increase the risk of bleeding when used with anticoagulants like warfarin.
interactionsWithMedications.antiplatelet drugs: May also increase bleeding risk when used with drugs that affect platelet function.

name: Motherwort
preparationMethods: Dried herb steeped in hot water with linden blossom
Can be taken as a tea, tincture, or in capsule form
cautions: Not recommended for pregnant women due to its uterine stimulating effects
Consult a healthcare provider before use if nursing
sourceReferences: Herbs for Health and Healing - Kathi Keville
The Complete Illustrated Holistic Herbal: A Safe and Practical Guide to Making and Using Herbal Remedies - David Hoffmann
growingInformation: Perennial plant, grows well in partial shade, needs well-aerated soils
harvestingInformation: Harvest right before or during blooming period (mid summer to fall)
activeConstituents: Iridoids (such as leonurine), Flavonoids (including rutin), tannins

dosageInformation.adult: Tea: 1-3 cup daily; Tincture: 10-40 drops 3 times daily
dosageInformation.elderly: Lower dose, consult a healthcare provider

shelfLife: Dried herbs up to 1-2 years if stored properly
storageInstructions: Store in an airtight container away from sunlight and heat
interactionsWithMedications: May potentiate anticoagulant medications
Can interfere with sedatives and blood pressure medications
